column43:
1. The construction of ば~ほど is very close in meaning to 'the more ~, the more ~' construction in English.

2. Other conditionals たら and と cannot be used in this construction. Thus, the following use of と and たら are ungrammatical.

    (1)
  • 授業料は{安ければ/*安いと}安いほどいい。
  • As for the tuition, the cheaper the better.
    (2)
  • 玄米は{かめば/*かんだら}かむほど味が出る。
  • As for brown rice, the more you chew it, the tastier it becomes.

3. When the verb is a する verb as in Key Sentence (A), it takes the form of either Noun すれば Noun するほど or Noun すればするほど as in Key Sentence (A). If the verb is not a する verb as in Example (a), it always takes the form of Verb conditional Verb informal nonpast ほど.

4. The conditional form なら is used only with Adjective な. So, the following sentences are ungrammatical.

    (3)
  • *この酒は飲むなら飲むほど美味しくなる。 [Correct formation= Example (a)]
    (4)
  • *アパートは駅に近いなら近いほど(家賃が)高い。 [Correct formation= Example (c)]
column44:
(i) V1 Conditional V2 Informal nonpast ほど Where Verb1=Verb2
  話せば話すほど The more someone talks, the more ~
(ii) Adjective い1 conditional Adjective い2 informal nonpast ほど Where Adjective い1 = Adjective い2
  高ければ高いほど The more expensive something is, the more ~
(iii) Adjective な1stem {であるばある / なら Adjective な2 stem な} ほど Where Adjective な1=Adjective な2
  {静かであるばある / 静かなら静かな} ほど The quieter something/someone is, the more ~

column2: A compound particle/conjunction which is used to connect two nouns or two sentences, the first of which is something normally expected and the second of which is something normally unexpected.

column43:
1. Before ばかりか comes something/someone normally expected and after ばかりか comes something/someone normally unexpected. If the order of the two is reversed an unacceptable sentence like the following results.

    (1)
  • *トムは平仮名が読めないばかりか、漢字さえ読めない。
  • [Correct formation= Example (c)]

2. The particle さえ can be replaced by the particle も especially in spoken Japanese.

    (2)
  • 僕の寮の部屋は狭いばかりか、窓もないんです。
  • [Correct formation= Example (b)]
    (3)
  • トムは漢字が読めないばかりか、平仮名も読めない。
  • [Correct formation= Example (c)]

【Related Expressions】

I. The pnrases ばかりで(は)なく~も and だけで(は)なく~も are very similar to ばかりか~(さえ). Among those three constructions ばかりか~(さえ) expresses the highest degree of unexpectedness between the content of Sentence1 and Sentence2. If such unexpectedness is missing, the ばかりか~(さえ) construction sounds awkward. Examples follow.

[1]

  • a. あの人は勉強{だけ/ばかり}で(は)なくスポーツもよく出来る。
  • He is not only good scholastically; he is also good at sports.
  • b. ??あの人は勉強ばかりか、スポーツさえ出来る。

[2]

  • a. この本は面白い{だけ/ばかり}で(は)なく、とてもためになる。
  • This book is not only interesting but also educational.
  • b. ??この本は面白いばかりかためにさえなる。

(⇨ だけで(は)なく~(も)㊦)

II. Sentence1 どころか Sentence2, a construction indicating that someone/something is very far from a/n (un)desirable state, is quite different from Sentence1 ばかりか Sentence2, when Sentence1 is affirmative and Sentence2 is negative or when Sentence1 is negative and Sentence2 is affirmative. Examples follow.

[3]

  • 日本語が話せる{どころか/*ばかりか}、一度も勉強したことがありません。
  • I am far from being able to speak Japanese; I haven't studied it at all.

[4]

  • スミスさんは日本語が書けない{どころか/*ばかりか}、日本語で小説さえ書ける。
  • Mr. Smith is far from being unable to write Japanese; he can even write a novel in Japanese.

If both Sentence1 and Sentence2 are affirmative or negative, the two constructions are interchangeable.

[5]

  • クラークさんは日本語が話せる{どころか/ばかりか}、韓国語さえ話せる。
  • Mr. Clark is not only able to speak Japanese; he can even speak Korean.

[6]

  • ジムは日本語で会話が出来ない{どころか/ばかりか}、簡単な挨拶も出来ない。
  • Jim is not only unable to converse in Japanese; he cannot even make simple greetings.

(iii) {Noun /Nounだった} ばかりか

column43:
1. Tense and negation are expressed by conjugating べきだ. [See Key Sentences (A) - (D) and Examples (a) - (d).]

2. The prenominal form of べきだ (i.e., the form which modifies a noun) is べき. [See Key Sentence (E) and Examples (g) - (i).]

3. べきだ usually expresses the idea that someone/something should do something or be in some state because it is his/her responsibility or duty, because it is the right thing or a good thing to do, or because it is the right state or a good state to be in. [See Key Sentence (A) - (E), Examples (a) - (f) and (i).]

4. べきだ also expresses the idea that someone is expected to do s.t. [See Examples (g) and (h).]

5. Adjective い stem+くあるべきだ, as in (1), is a possible form but this form is not commonly used.

    (1)
  • 体は年をとっても心は若くあるべきだ。
  • Even if one's body gets old, one's mind should be young.

6. べきだ is not used when the speaker is younger than the hearer or lower than the hearer in status. For example, (2) is not appropriate in the given situation.

    (2) [From a student to his/her professor]
  • ??先生、それはお忘れになるべきです。
  • Professor, you should forget it.

【Related Expressions】

I. ものだ also expresses the idea that one should do something as one's duty, as in [1].

[1]

  • 学生は勉強するものだ。
  • Students should study.

However, ものだ is used only in a generic statement to express a social norm. Thus, in a specific situation, as in [2], it cannot be used.

[2]

  • 君は勉強する{べき/*もの}だ。
  • You should study.

(⇨ もの(だ)㊦)

II. In terms of forcefulness, べきだ is weaker than なければならない and stronger than たほうがいい, as in [3].

[3]

a. 君はもっと勉強しなければならな。 stronger
You must study harder ↑
b. 君はもっと勉強すべきだ。 |
You should study harder. |
c. 君はもっと勉強した方がいい。 ↓
You'd better study harder. weaker

(⇨ なければならない㊦; ほうがいい㊦

III. はず also expresses the idea of "should." However, はず is used when the speaker's expectation is involved. Compare the following sentences.

[4]

  • a. このレポートは山田さんが書き直すはずだ。
  • Yamada should rewrite this report. (= I expect that Yamada will rewrite this report.)
  • b. このレポートは山田さんが書き直すべきだ。
  • Yamada should rewrite this report. (= Rewriting this report is Yamada's duty.)

[5]

  • a. この本はここの図書館にあるはずだ。
  • This book should be in this library. (= I expect that this book is in this library.)
  • b. この本はここの図書館にあるべきだ。
  • This book should be in this library. (= Housing this book is this library's responsibility.)

(⇨ はず㊦)

  目的であるべきだ Something should be an objective

column43:
Either a number+counter or a noun precedes 分. When a number+counter precedes, it means something worth that amount (e.g., Key Sentence (A)) or equivalent to that amount (e.g., Key Sentence (B)). When a noun precedes 分, it means the amount or portion of something represented by the noun (e.g., Key Sentence (C)).

【Related Expression】

The suffix 前 also expresses a portion of something, as in [1], but this use is limited to food. A number+人 precedes 前.

[1]

  • 吉田は寿司を五人前平らげだ。
  • Yoshida ate five orders of sushi.

column43:
だが is not used in spoken Japanese unless it is followed by ね as in (1).

    (1)
  • A: あの男はなかなか切れるな。
  • That guy is really sharp, isn't he?
  • B: だがね、奴は性格が悪いんだ。
  • But, he has a bad character, you know.

In spoken Japanese it is usually replaced either by けれど(も) or by でも. The formal version ですが can be used in both spoken and written Japanese.

    (2)
  • A: 仕事はお忙しいでしょう。
  • Your job must keep you busy.
  • B: ええ、{でも/ですが/けれども}、面白いんです。
  • Yes, but it is interesting.
    (3)
  • 日本へ行きたくて仕方がないんです。{でも/ですが/けれども}、お金がないから、行けません。
  • I'm dying to go to Japan. But I don't have money, so I can't go there.

【Related Expression】

The first difference between だが and が/けれど(も) /のに/しかし/だけど/でも is the way they combine two sentences. だが, だけど, しかし and でも are always used as a sentence-initial conjunction, but が and のに are normally used as a non-sentence-initial conjunction, and けれど(も) is used either as a sentence-initial conjunction or a non-sentence-initial conjunction.

Sentence-initial conjunctions:

a. Sentence1。だがSentence2。 *Sentence1だがだが、Sentence2。
b. Sentence1。だけどSentence2。 *Sentence1だけど、Sentence2。
c. Sentence1。しかしSentence2。 *Sentence1しかし、Sentence2。
d. Sentence1。でもSentence2。 *Sentence1でも、Sentence2。

Non-sentence-initial conjunctions:

e. Sentence1が、Sentence2。 ???Sentence1。がSentence2。
f. Sentence1のに、Sentence2。 *Sentence1。のにSentence2。

(Non-)Sentence-initial conjunction:

g. Sentence1けれど(も)、Sentence2。 Sentence1。けれど(も)、Sentence2。

The second difference concerns semantic difference. が and けれど(も) can be used to in two senses of 'but' and 'and.'

[1]

  • 今東京に来ています{が/けれど/*のに}、東京は、やはり、活気がありますね。
  • I'm in Tokyo now, and I feel that Tokyo is full of energy, after all.

For the difference between けれど(も) and のに, see のに. (⇨ のに㊦) Among the four sentence-initial conjunctions, the most colloquial is でも, followed by だけど and the least colloquial one is だが, followed by しかし.

column43:
1. だからと言って is a conjuction which indicates that while the speaker/writer accepts an assertion/fact in the preceding sentence, he argues that what is normally expected from the assertion/fact is not (necessarily) applicable. Thus, for example, Sentence1 and Sentence2 of Key Sentence (A) may lead to an assertion that Mr. Cheng is not smart. But the speaker denies that extrapolation in Sentence3. To paraphrase it, it is something like: 'Mr. Cheng is poor at Japanese and he can't even get half way through tests. So you probably think he is not smart, but I don't think that’s true.'

2. だからと言って often occurs with わけではない or とは限らない, as shown in all the examples except Example (d).

column43:
The choice of the tense of the verb before だけ depends on (1) whether or not the action expressed by the verb (Action 1) was taken in the past, and (2) whether or not the action/event expressed by the verb (Action 1) precedes the action/event expressed by the main verbal (Action 2). If A1 precedes A2 and A1 is a past action, the verb must be in the past tense (example, Key Sentence (B) and Example (e)). If A1 precedes A2 and A1 is not a past action, the verb is commonly in the nonpast tense, although the past tense is also acceptable (example, Examples (f) - (h)). If A1 does not precede A2 and A1 is a past action, the verb is commonly in the nonpast, although the past tense is also acceptable (example, Example (d)). If A1 does not precede A2 and A1 is not a past action, the verb must be in the nonpast (example, Key Sentence (A) and Examples(a) - (c)).

(⇨ だけ㊦)
column44:
V informal だけで

column2: A suffix that indicates that something/someone is covered or filled with something undesirable.
column3: Full of; filled with; covered with
column9: (ksa).　スミスさんはいつも泥○○の靴を履いています。
column10: (ksa).　スミスさんはいつも泥だらけの靴を履いています。

column16: (b).　病院に担ぎ込んだ時、その男の顔は血だらけだった。
column17: When we carried him into the hospital, the  man's face was covered with blood.
column18: (c).　泥だらけの足で入って来ないで。
column19: Don't come in with muddy feet.
column20: (d).　借金だらけの生活をしています。

column22: (e).　この貝は砂だらけで食べにくい。
column23: This seashell contains a lot of sand, so  eating is difficult.
column43:
だらけ is used when something is covered with something undesirable, but if something is covered with something desirable だらけ cannot be used.

    (1)
  • 床の上{には札束がゴロゴロしていた/*は札束だらけだった}。
  • On the floor were scattered bundles of money.
    (2)
  • その学生の論文{にはいいアイディアがいっぱいあった/*はいいアイディアだらけだった}。
  • In the student’s paper there were a lot of good ideas.

【Related Expression】

The difference between だらけ and まみれ is that the latter means 'totally covered/mixed with dirty liquid/powder such as blood, sweat, mud or dust,' excluding intangible objects, whereas the former can be used not only with liquid/powder but also to cover holes/pimples, and intangible objects, as in Key Sentence (B) and Example (d). More examples to show the difference follow:

[1]

  • 私の作文は訂正{だらけ/*まみれ}だった。
  • My composition was full of corrections.

[2]

  • 僕のズボンは穴{だらけ/*まみれ}だ。
  • My pants are full of holes.

[3]

  • 少年の顔はにきび{だらけ/*まみれ}だった。
  • The boy's face was covered with pimples.

[4]

  • 凸凹{だらけ/*まみれ}の道を三時間も運転して、疲れてしまった。
  • I got tired after driving on a bumpy road for as long as three hours.

column24: (e).　ガールフレンドを喜ばせようとしたのに、逆に怒らせてしまった。
column25: I tried to please my girlfriend, but,  contrary to my intention, I made her angry.
column26: (f).　その試験に落ちるだろうと思っていたのに、逆に一番で通ってしまった。
column27: I was expecting to fail the exam, but,  contrary to my expectation, I passed it in first place.
column28: (g).　人に親切にすることは一般にいいことだと考えられている。しかし、親切にすることが、逆に人を傷つけることもある。
column29: In general, being kind to people is  considered to be a good thing. However, contrary to one's intention, being kind  sometimes hurts people.
column30: (h).　この子は優しくすると付け上がる。逆に厳しくするとすぐ泣く。
column31: If I try to be gentle to the boy, he takes advantage of my gentleness. Conversely, if I try to be strict, he cries readily.
column32: (i).　いい演技をする為には緊張しすぎてはいけない。しかし、逆にリラックスしすぎてもいい演技は出来ない。
column33: In order to perform well, you mustn't be too  tense. But, conversely, if you are too relaxed, you cannot perform well,  either.

column2: A particle which indicates the extent or the degree to which someone/something does something or is in some state.
column3: The ~, the ~; as; to the extent
column9: (ksa).　この音楽は舞台に近い○○聞きやすい。
column10: (ksa).　この音楽は舞台に近いほど聞きやすい。

column12: (ksb).　上空に行くほど酸素が薄くなる。
column13: Oxygen is less dense at higher altitudes.  (literally: Oxygen becomes thinner as you go higher / the extent to which you  go higher in the air.)
column14: (ksc).　私は難しい仕事ほどやる気が出てくる。
column15: I get more motivated by a harder job.
column16: (a).　子供は小言を言うほど反発するものだ。
column17: The more you nag children, the more they  disobey you.
column18: (b).　私は静かなほど落ち着かない。
column19: The quieter it is, the more uneasy I feel.
column20: (c).　駅に近くなるほど家賃が高くなる。
column21: The closer to the station, the higher the  rent.
column22: (d).　運動するほど体の調子が変になる。
column23: The more I exercise, the worse I feel.
column24: (e).　元気な人ほど無理をしがちだ。
column25: Stronger people tend to strain themselves  more.
column26: (f).　あまり働かない者ほど不平が多い。
column27: Lazier people complain more.
column44:
(i) {V/Adjective い}informal nonpast ほど  
  勉強するほど The more someone studies
  高いほど The more expensive something is
(ii) Adjective な stem {な/である} ほど  
  便利{な/である} ほど The more convenient something is
(iii) Relative Clause+Noun ほど  
  考え方が論理的な人ほど The more logical a person’s way of thinking is

column2: A dependent noun which means "something/someone other than".
column3: Other than; except (for); but; besides; as well as

column26: (f).　ここで待っている以外ない。

column28: (g).　安い以外に何かいいことがありますか。

column44:
(i) Noun 以外(のNoun)

  勉強する以外 Besides studying
  高い以外 Besides the fact that something is expensive

  先生である以外 Besides the fact that someone is a teacher

column2: A conjunction indicating the speaker/writer's feeling that there should be a very strong logical/natural connection between wht precedes the conjunction and what follows it.
column3: Since; now that; once; if ~ at all; as long as; so long as

column13: So long as you are a student, you should  study.
column14: (a).　日本語を始めた以上、よく話せて、聞けて、読めて、書けるようになるまで頑張ります。
column15: Now that I have begun to study Japanese, I  will hang in there until I can speak and understand what I hear, and read and  write well.
column16: (b).　新車を買う以上は、出来るだけ燃費のいいのを買いたいです。
column17: If I buy a new car at all, I would like to  buy one with good gas mileage.
column18: (c).　親である以上、子供の教育に関心があるのは当然でしょう。
column19: If you are any sort of parent, you should be  interested in your child's education.
column20: (d).　貰った以上は、あなたが何と言おうと、私の物です。
column21: Now that you have given this to me, it is  mine, no matter what you say.
column22: (e).　体をよく動かしている以上は、人間の体は衰えないらしい。
column23: So long as you are very active, your body  seems to stay strong.
column24: (f).　人と約束した以上は、それを守らなければならない。
column25: Once you have made a promise to someone, you  have to keep it.
column44:
(i) Vinformal 以上(は)  
  先生である以上は As long as someone is a teacher
column46: 【Related Expression: 限り(は); からには】

column2: An adverb that indicates the speaker/writer's emotive conviction.
column3: Really; truly; indeed
column9: (ksa).　アメリカ人の目から見ると、日本の社会は○○閉鎖的だ。
column10: (ksa).　アメリカ人の目から見ると、日本の社会はいかにも閉鎖的だ。

column14: (ksc).　彼の書斎の本棚には古今東西の本が詰まっていて、いかにも学者の部屋らしい。
column15: The bookshelves of his study room are packed  with books of all ages and countries, and it surely looks like a scholar's  room.
column16: (ksd).　先生は最近いかにもお忙しいよう / 様子だ。
column17: These days the professor appears to be really  busy.
column18: (kse).　日本人は集団行動がいかにも好きではあるが、個人行動をしないわけではない。
column19: The Japanese indeed like group behaviour, but  it is not the case that they do not behave individually.
column20: (ksf).　彼はいかにも紳士であるかのように振る舞っているが、なかなかの策士だ。
column21: He is behaving as if he were truly a  gentleman, but he is quite calculated.
column22: (a).　彼の発想はいかにも日本的だ。
column23: His manner of thinking is very Japanese.
column24: (b).　その教授の知識はいかにも百科全書的だ。
column25: The professor's knowledge is really  encyclopaedic.
column26: (c).　デーヴィッドは文部省の奨学金が貰えて、いかにも嬉しそうだった。
column27: David was able to get a Ministry of Education scholarship and he looked really happy about it.
column28: (d).　父は退院して、いかにも元気そうになった。
column29: My father left the hospital and became really  healthy-looking.
column30: (e).　彼女は明るく、陽気で、いかにもアメリカ人らしい。
column31: She is light-hearted and cheerful, and is  truly like an American.
column32: (f).　僕の大学の友人はいかにも金持ちらしく、いつも洒落た物を着ている。
column33: A friend of mine in college appears to be  truly rich, and is always wearing fancy clothes.
column34: (g).　ジョンは恋人と別れて、いかにも落ち込んでいるようだった。
column35: John split up with his girlfriend and looked  truly depressed.
column36: (h).　みゆきは母を失って、いかにも悲しんでいる様子だった。
column37: Miyuki lost her mother and looked really saddened.
column38: (i).　いかにもおっしゃる通りです。
column39: It is exactly as you have said.
column40: (j).　日本語はいかにも難しい言語ではあるが、マスター出来ないわけではない。
column41: Japanese is indeed a difficult language, but  it is not the case that you cannot master it.

column2: Verb forms which indicate commands or requests.

column10: (ksa).　もうよせよ。

column44:
(i) Group 1 verbs Vconditional Affirmative
  書け Write!
(ii) Group 2 verbs Vstem {ろ (spoken)/ よ(written)} Affirmative
  答えろ Answer!
  答えよ Answer!
(iii) Irregular verbs   Affirmative
  来い Come!
  しろ Do! (spoken)
  せよ Do (written)
(iv) Vinformal nonpast な Negative
  話すな Don’t talk!
  食べるな Don’t eat!

column1: 一方で（は） ~ 他方で（は）
column2: A structure used to describe two concurring, contrastive actions/states of someone or something.
column3: On the one hand ~, on the other hand
column9: (ks).　神田先生は、○○大学で物理学を教えながら、○○日本語の研究をなさっている。
column10: (ks).　神田先生は、一方では大学で物理学を教えながら、他方では日本語の研究をなさっている。
column11: Professor Kanda teaches physics at college on  the one hand and does research on Japanese language on the other.
column12: (a).　あの男は、一方では静かな日本画を描いたりしているが、他方ではサッカーのような激しいスポーツをしている。
column13: That man draws quiet Japanese paintings on  the one hand, but plays a very competitive sport like soccer on the other.
column14: (b).　Ｘ氏は、一方で慈善事業をやりながら、他方でかなりあくどい商売をしているという噂だ。
column15: On one hand, Mr. X is engaged in charities,  but, on the other hand, rumour has it that he is engaged in a ruthless  business.
column16: (c).　あの大統領は、一方では減税を約束しておきながら、他方では側近の税金の無駄使いをあまり重要視していない。
column17: The President has promised tax-cuts. But on  the other hand he doesn't think much about waste of taxpayers' money by his  entourage.
column18: (d).　留守番電話は、一方ではかかる方にもかける方にも便利な面もあるが、他方ではお互いに直接話が出来ないから、不自然な面もある。
column19: The answering machine is, on the one hand,  very convenient for both a person who calls and a person who is called, but, on  the other hand, unnatural because you can't talk directly with the other  person.
column20: (e).　ストレスは、一方では害になることもあるが、他方では生活のいい刺激にもなるそうだ。
column21: It is said that stress is sometimes harmful  for humans, but, on the other hand, it also seems to be a good stimulus for  human life.
column22: (f).　外国生活は、一方では新しい文化に接することが出来て楽しい面もあるが、他方ではカルチャーショックで大変困ることもある。
column23: Life in a foreign country is, on the one  hand, enjoyable because one can encounter new culture,  but, on the other hand, it is sometimes hard because of culture shock.
column44:
Nounは 一方ではS1 Conjunction,他方ではS2  
  この薬は、一方では症状を軽くするが、他方では強い副作用がある This medicine, on (the) one hand, alleviates symptoms but on the other hand, it has strong side effects

column2: A suffix which indicates the idea of "from the viewpoint of," "for the sake of," "for the reason," or "in terms of".
column3: From the viewpoint of; for (the sake of); for (the reason); in (terms of); relating to; in –ing
column9: (ksa).　この映画は教育○○よくない。

column11: This film is not good from an educational  point of view.

column17: In terms of calculation, this is correct.
column18: (kse).　健康上の理由で引退することにした。
column19: I've decided to retire for health reasons  (literally: for a reason relating to my health).
column20: (ksf).　「使用上の注意」をよく読んで下さい。
column21: Read "Warnings for Use" carefully.
column22: (a).　このような行為は道義上許せない。

column24: (b).　この条件はこれからの取引上極めて不利だ。

column29: For business-related reasons, I cannot leave  this town.
column30: (e).　理論上はこうなるはずなのだが、実際どうなるかは分からない。
column31: In theory it should turn out like this, but  it's not known how it will actually turn out.
column32: (f).　法律上は彼の行為は罪にならない。
column33: Legally his conduct is not criminal.
column34: (g).　この製品にはデザイン上の欠陥がいくつかある。
column35: This product has some design defects.
column36: (h).　彼女は一身上の都合で会社を辞めることになった。
column37: She is going to quit her company for personal  reasons.
column38: (i).　この部品は製作上いくつかの問題がある。
column39: There are some problems in manufacturing this  part.
column44:
Noun 上  
  衛生上 From the viewpoint of hygiene

column2: Contrary to one's expectation an opposite result comes about.
column3: On the contrary; rather
column9: (ks).　薬を飲んだら、○○病気がひどくなった。
column10: (ks).　薬を飲んだら、かえって病気がひどくなった。
column11: I took medicine, and the illness got worse  (contrary to my expectation).

column15: I went to Japan, believing that my Japanese  will improve (if I go) there, but I spoke only in English with Japanese there,  so (contrary to my expectation) my Japanese became worse when I came back here.
column16: (c).　就職のことで三人の先生にアドバイスをしてもらったのですが、アドバイスが全然違うので、かえって、分からなくなってしまいました。
column17: I was given advice on job searching from  three professors, but their advices are so different that I am rather at a  loss.
column18: (d).　いわゆる一流大学で勉強するより小さな私立大学で勉強する方が、かえって、いい教育を受けることが出来る。
column19: (Contrary to your expectation) if you study  at a small, private college, you can receive better education than to study at  the so-called first-rate university.
column20: (e).　アルコールも適量飲めば、かえって、体にいいそうだ。
column21: Alcohol is said to be rather good for your  health if you drink it in moderate quantity.

column2: A conjunction which expresses the idea "as long as (a certain condition is met)" or "as long as (= to the extent)".
column3: As long as; as far as; while; to the extent; until; unless
column9: (ksa).　私がここにいる○○心配は無用です。
column10: (ksa).　私がここにいる限り心配は無用です。
column11: As long as I am here, you don't have to  worry.
column12: (ksb).　田中さんが来ない限りこの会議は始められない。
column13: As long as Mr. Tanaka is not here (literally:  does not come), we cannot begin this meeting.
column14: (ksc).　これが事実である限り彼は有罪を免れないだろう。
column15: As long as this is the fact, he probably  cannot escape being found guilty.
column16: (a).　今の状態が続く限りプロジェクトは始められない。
column17: As long as the present situation continues,  we cannot start out project.
column18: (b).　この事件に関する限り彼は無実だ。
column19: As long as this incident is concerned, he is  innocent.
column20: (c).　私の知っている限り彼は正直者です。
column21: As far as I know, he is an honest man.
column22: (d).　その書類は私が読んだ限り誤りはなかった。
column23: As far as I read, the document contained no  errors.
column24: (e).　教育者である限りそんなことは口にすべきではない。
column25: While you are an educator, you shouldn't say  things like that.
column26: (f).　この試験に通らない限り上級クラスに入れません。
column27: Until you pass this exam, you cannot enrol in  the advanced class.
column28: (g).　事態が変わらない限り今以上の援助は不可能です。
column29: Until the situation changes (literally: As  long as the situation doesn't change), we cannot provide additional support.
column30: (h).　アメリカ人でない限りこの仕事には就けない。
column31: Unless you are an American, you cannot be  employed for this job.
column32: (i).　私達は力の続く限り漕いだ。
column33: We rowed as long as our strength lasted  (literally: to the extent that our strength lasted).
column34: (j).　出来る限りやってみます。
column35: I will try my best (literally: try to do as  long as I can do).
column44:
(i) Vinformal 限り  
  見る限り As far as someone sees
  調べた限り As long as someone examined
  読まない限り As long as someone does not read; until someone reads
  出来る限り As long as someone can do; to the extent someone can do
(ii) Nounで {ある/ない}限り  
  学生である限り As long as someone is a student; while someone is a student
  日本人でない限り As long as someone is not Japanese; unless someone is Japanese
column46: 【Related Expression: あいだは; うちは】

column2: A suffix which expresses the idea of "(last) only until" or "limited".
column3: The last; only until; from ~ on; limited to; only
column9: (ksa).　今度○○で彼のパーティーには行かないつもりだ。

column16: (b).　今日限りで酒も煙草もやめます。

column18: (c).　セールは明日限りです。

column20: (d).　その場限りの約束はしない方がいい。

(i) Noun (time) 限り

(ii) Number+Counter 限り  
  一度限り Limited to one time; only once

column2: A structure to mark two choices or possibilities about which the speaker/writer is not sure.
column3: Whether ~ or; or

column15: I haven't decided yet whether to get a job or  go to graduate school after graduation from college.
column16: (b).　お客さんが肉が好きか魚が好きか、聞いておいて下さい。
column17: Please ask the guest in advance whether he  likes meat or fish.
column18: (c).　夏休みにはヨーロッパを旅行するか、ソウルで仕事をするか、まだ決めていません。
column19: I haven't yet decided whether I should travel  in Europe or work in Seoul during the summer break.
column20: (d).　会議が木曜日だったか金曜日だったか、忘れてしまいました。
column21: I forgot whether the meeting was on Thursday  or Friday.
column22: (e).　初めてタマラと会ったのがパーティーでだったか、プールでだったか、覚えていません。
column23: I don't remember whether it was at a party or  at the pool that I first met Tamara.
column24: (f).　木村さんが大学で経済を専攻したのか、政治を専攻したのか、知っていますか。
column25: Do you know whether Mr. Kimura majored in  economics or politics at college?
column26: (g).　最近は男か、男でないか、分からないような男が多い。
column27: Lately, it's hard to tell whether a lot of  men are men or not.
column28: (h).　会議は月曜か水曜（か）にして下さい。
column29: Please make the meeting Monday or Wednesday.
column44:
(i) {V1/Adjective い1} informal か {V2/Adjective い2} informal か  
  {遊ぶ/遊んだ} か {勉強する/勉強した} か Whether someone plays/played or studies/studied
  {面白い/面白かった} か {つまらない/つまらなかった} か Whether something is/was interesting or boring
(ii) {Adjectiveな1 stem/ Noun1} {Ø/だった} か {Adjectiveな2 stem/Noun2}{Ø/だった} か  
  {便利/便利だった} か {不便/不便だった} か Whether something is/was convenient or inconvenient
  {男/男だった} か {女/女だった} か Whether someone is/was a man or a woman
(iii) {Adjectiveな1 stem/ Noun1} {Ø/だった} か {Adjectiveな2 stem/Noun2}negative か Where Adjective な1= Adjective な2,Noun1=Noun2
  {便利/便利だった} か 便利{じゃ/で} {ない / なかった} か Whether something is/was convenient or not
  {男/男だった} か 男{じゃ/で} {ない / なかった} か Whether someone is/was a man or not

column2: A sentence-final particle that indicates a self-addressed question or a question addressed to an in-group member.
column3: I wonder if ~
column9: (ksa).　今週末には何をしよう○○。
column10: (ksa).　今週末には何をしようかな。
column11: I wonder what I should do this weekend.
column12: (ksb).　この問題、君に分かるかな。
column13: Can you figure out this problem?
column14: (a).　今日は何曜日だったかな。
column15: I wonder what day of the week today is.
column16: (b).　来学期から日本語を始めようかな。
column17: I wonder if I should start Japanese next  semester.
column18: (c).　日本での生活はどうかな。
column19: I wonder what life is like in Japan.
column20: (d).　今日の晩ご飯は何かな。
column21: I wonder what today's dinner will be.
column22: (e).　アパートの家賃は高いかな。
column23: I wonder if the apartment rent is high.
column24: (f).　先生はお元気かな。
column25: I wonder if my teacher is in good health.
column26: (g).　音楽会の切符があるんだけど、君は行けるかな。
column27: There is a concert ticket, but I wonder if  you can go.
column44:
(i) {V/Vvolitional} informal かな  
  {話す/話した/話そう} かな I wonder if someone talks/if someone talked/if I should talk
(ii) Adjective い informal かな  
  {大きい/大きかった} かな I wonder if something is/was big
(iii) {Adjective な stem/Noun} {Ø/だった} かな  
  静か{Ø/だった} かな I wonder if something is/was quiet
  先生{Ø/だった} かな I wonder if someone is/was a teacher
(iv) Wh-word {Ø/だった} かな  
  いつ{Ø/だった} かな I wonder when something is/was

column2: An adverb that indicates that the proposition expressed in the sentence is not always true.
column3: Not always; not necessarily
column9: (ksa).　頭のいい人が、○○成功するとは限らない。
column10: (ksa).　頭のいい人が、必ずしも成功するとは限らない。
column11: A bright person does not always succeed.
column12: (ksb).　高い料理が必ずしも美味しいわけではない。
column13: Expensive dishes are not always delicious.
column14: (ksc).　記憶力のいい人が必ずしも外国語が上手だとは言えない。
column15: One cannot always say that people with good  memories are good at foreign languages.
column16: (ksd).　日本人が必ずしもいい日本語の先生だとは思わない。
column17: I don't think that a Japanese is always a  good Japanese language teacher.
column18: (a).　結婚しても必ずしも幸福になるとは言えない。
column19: One cannot always say that marriage brings  happiness.
column20: (b).　運動をよくする人が必ずしも長生きするとは限らない。
column21: People who exercise regularly do not always  live long.
column22: (c).　日本へ行った学生が日本語が上手になるかというと、必ずしもそうではない。
column23: Students who have been to Japan do not always  become proficient in Japanese.
column24: (d).　お金は人を必ずしも幸福にはしない。
column25: Money does not always bring happiness to  people.
column26: (e).　優れた研究者が必ずしも優れた教育者であるわけではない。
column27: It is not always the case that an able  researcher is an able educator.
column28: (f).　良薬は口に苦しと言うが、苦い薬が必ずしもいいとは限らない。
column29: They say good medicine is bitter, but bitter  medicine is not always good.
column30: (g).　眼鏡をかけて、カメラを下げて、集団で歩いている東洋人が必ずしも日本人ではない。
column31: An oriental wearing glasses, carrying a  camera and walking in a group is not always a Japanese.
column44:
(i) 必ずしも{Vinformal/Adjectiveい} とは{限ら /言え/思わ}ない  
  必ずしも{静か/先生}ではない Something is not always quiet/someone is not always a teacher
column46: 【Related Expression: いつもは~ない; みんなは~ない; 全ては~ない; 全部は~ない】

column2: An auxiliary expressing that someone cannot do something even if s/he wants to do it.
column3: Cannot; be not in a position to; hardly possible; hard; hesitate to do
column9: (ksa).　そのことは私には分かり○○から、部長にお聞きになって下さい。
column10: (ksa).　そのことは私には分かりかねますから、部長にお聞きになって下さい。
column11: I am not in a position to figure out that  matter, so please ask the departmental chief.
column12: (ksb).　あの男はどんな馬鹿なことでもやりかねない。
column13: He might (literally: can) do any stupid  thing.
column14: (a).　来週はロンドンへ出張しますので、誠に申し訳ございませんが、名古屋での会議には出席できかねます。
column15: Next week I am making a business trip to  London, so I cannot attend the meeting in Nagoya.
column16: (b).　これだけの書類を一月では処理いたしかねますが。
column17: I cannot handle this many documents in a  month.
column18: (c).　大変遺憾に存じますが、ご依頼には応じかねます。
column19: It is a great regret, but we cannot comply  with your request.
column20: (d).　こんな高価な贈り物、頂きかねます。
column21: I cannot accept such an expensive gift.
column22: (e).　彼は私の気持ちを量りかねているようだ。
column23: He appears to find it hard to understand my  feelings.
column24: (f).　非常に言いにくいことなので、さすがの部長も切り出しかねている。
column25: It is such a delicate matter, so even the  departmental chief finds it hard to break the ice.
column26: (g).　みどりさん、ご主人がお待ちかねよ。
column27: Midori, your husband is waiting for you with  impatience (literally: cannot wait).
column28: (h).　あいつはとんでもないことを言いかねないから、注意した方がいいよ。
column29: He might say outrageous things, so watch out.
column30: (i).　あの男はちょっとしたことで暴力を振るいかねない。
column31: That man might use violence at the slightest  provocation.
column32: (j).　この事件は内閣総辞職にも発展しかねない。
column33: It is possible for this incident to develop  into resignation of the entire cabinet.
column34: (k).　暴動すら起こりかねないような緊迫した情況だった。
column35: It was such a tense situation that even a  riot could have taken place.
column44:
Vます かねる/かねない  
  飲みかねる Someone cannot drink something
  飲みかねない It is possible for someone to drink something/someone might drink something

column2: A structure that expresses a wide range of things.
column3: Starting with ~ ending with ~; from ~ to ~
column9: (ks).　スミスさんは週刊誌○○学術書○○、幅広い日本語が読める。
column10: (ks).　スミスさんは週刊誌から学術書に至るまで、幅広い日本語が読める。
column11: Mr. Smith can read Japanese widely, ranging  from weekly magazines to scholastic books.
column12: (a).　その新聞記者は首相の公の生活から私生活に至るまで、何でも知っている。
column13: That newspaper reporter knows everything  about the premier, ranging from his public life to his private life.
column14: (b).　私が日本へ行った時、友人の山田さんは空港への出迎えからホテルの予約に至るまで、実に親切にしてくれた。
column15: When I went to Japan, my friend Mr. Yamada  was very kind to me. He did everything from picking me up at the airport to  making the hotel reservation for me.
column16: (c).　その女の人は私に家族のことから自分の悩みに至るまで、細かに話した。
column17: That lady told me everything in detail,  starting with her family and ending with the worries of her life.
column18: (d).　社長が現れた時には、守衛から副社長に至るまで、門の前で待っていた。
column19: When the president of the company arrived,  everyone from the guards to the vice-president was waiting in front of the  gate.
column20: (e).　ルーシーは靴から帽子に至るまで、緑の装束だった。
column21: Lucy was dressed in green, from her shoes to  her hat.
column45: Structure(used in writing and formal speech only)

column2: A structure that expresses coverage from one time/location into the other.
column3: Through ~ into ~; through ~ on to; from ~ till/to
column9: (ks).　今年の夏、七月○○八月○○中国大陸を旅行した。
column10: (ks).　今年の夏、七月から八月にかけて中国大陸を旅行した。
column11: This  summer I travelled on the Chinese continent from July through August.
column12: (a).　今週は木曜から金曜にかけて雪が降るでしょう。
column13: This  week it will probably snow from Thursday through Friday.
column14: (b).　日本は六月から七月にかけて梅雨が続く。
column15: In  Japan the rainy season continues through June and July.
column16: (c).　高気圧が朝鮮半島から九州にかけて張り出している。
column17: High  atmospheric pressure extends from the Korean Peninsula up through Kyushu.
column44:
Noun からNounにかけて  
  一月から二月にかけて From January through February

column2: A conjunction which introduces the reason for someone's action or for someone's having some idea, and conveys disapproval of the action or idea.
column3: Just because; even if; even though
column9: (ksa).　子供だ○○許すわけにはいかない。
column10: (ksa).　子供だからと言って許すわけにはいかない。
column11: I  cannot forgive him just because he is a child.
column12: (ksb).　何も不平を言わないからと言って現状に満足しているわけではない。
column13: Even  though I don't complain, it doesn't mean that I'm satisfied with the present  situation.
column14: (ksc).　試験に受からなかったからと言ってそんなに悲観することはない。
column15: You  don't have to be so pessimistic because you didn't pass the exam.
column16: (a).　弁償したからと言って済む問題ではない。
column17: It  is not a problem which will be solved because you have paid / will pay  compensation.
column18: (b).　上司の命令だからと言って黙って従うわけにはいかない。
column19: I  cannot obey the order without asking questions even if it is from my boss.
column20: (c).　アメリカへ行ったからと言って勝手に英語が上手になるものではない。
column21: Your  English will not improve (itself / automatically) even if you go to America.
column22: (d).　毎日授業に出ているからと言って真面目に勉強していることにはならない。
column23: Even  though he goes to class every day, it doesn't mean that he is studying  seriously.
column24: (e).　こんなことを言うからと言って別に批判しているわけではない。
column25: Even  though I tell you such a thing, it doesn't mean that I'm criticizing you.
column26: (f).　自分の問題じゃないからと言って知らん顔をしているのはよくない。
column27: It's  not right for you to be indifferent just because it's not your problem.
column28: (g).　女だからと言って侮ってはいけない。
column29: Don't  take her lightly just because she is a woman.
column44:
Sinformal からと言って  
  高いからと言って Because/even if/even though it is expensive
column46: 【Related Expression: から; たって; ても】

column2: An auxiliary indicating the writer's conjecture which is not based on any particular information or evidence.
column3: Probably
column9: (ks).　十年後の自分を予想するのは難し○○。
column10: (ks).　十年後の自分を予想するのは難しかろう。
column11: It  is probably difficult to predict what one's self will be like in ten years  time.
column12: (a).　この研究を一年で完成するのは極めて難しかろう。
column13: It  is probably extremely difficult to complete this research in one year.
column14: (b).　日本人の中にも創造性のない教育に反対する人は多かろう。
column15: Even  among the Japanese, there are probably a lot of people who oppose education  without creativity.
column16: (c).　私のように文化は宗教のようなものだと考えている人は少なかろう。
column17: Few  people probably think, as I do, that culture is something like religion.
column18: (d).　アメリカの大学のように、日本の大学でも学生に教師の評価をさせるとよかろう。
column19: It  would probably be good if Japanese universities allowed students to evaluate  instructors as American universities do.
column20: (e).　人種偏見ほど人間に根深いものはなかろう。
column21: Nothing  is probably as deep-rooted in humans as racial prejudices.
column22: (f).　近い将来に日米関係に大きな変化はなかろう。
column23: There  will probably not be a big change in the US-Japan relationship in the near  future.
column24: (g).　あの二人の間柄は親しくはなかろう。
column25: The  relationship between the two is probably not close.
column26: (h).　残業手当てを要求することは無理ではなかろう。
column27: It  is probably not unreasonable to ask for pay for overtime work.
column28: (i).　彼にはアリバイがあるのだから、犯人ではなかろう。
column29: He  has an alibi, so he is probably not the culprit.
column44:
(i) Adjective い stem かろう  
  面白かろう Someone/something is probably interesting
  よかろう Someone/something is probably good
  なかろう Someone/something does not probably exist
(ii) {Adjective い stem く (は)/Adjective な stem/Noun} なかろう  
  面白く(は)なかろう Someone/something is probably not interesting
  困難ではなかろう Something is probably not hard
  学者ではなかろう Someone is probably not a scholar
column45: Auxiliary(used in writing and formal speech only)

column2: A phrase to indicate a manner of doing something.
column3: Do something in a ~ fashion/manner/way
column9: (ksa).　林田先生は厳しい教え○○。
column10: (ksa).　林田先生は厳しい教え方をする。
column11: Professor  Hayashida teaches in a strict manner.
column12: (ksb).　昭は変わったものの見方をする。
column13: Akira  views things in a peculiar fashion.
column14: (ksc).　ブラウンさんは日本人のような考え方をする。
column15: Mr.  Brown thinks like the Japanese.
column16: (ksd).　誰にでも分かるような書き方をして下さい。
column17: Please  write in such a way that anyone can understand it.
column18: (a).　あのピッチャーは面白い投げ方をする。
column19: That  pitcher throws (a ball) in an interesting way.
column20: (b).　吉田君は乱暴な運転のし方をするので乗せてもらうのが怖い。
column21: I'm  afraid of getting a ride from Yoshida because he drives carelessly (literally:  in a wild fashion).
column22: (c).　正はほかの学生と違った勉強のし方をしているようだ。
column23: Tadashi  seems to study in a different way from other students.
column24: (d).　私には野村先生のような考え方は出来ない。
column25: I  cannot think like Professor Nomura.
column26: (e).　勉強が楽しくなるような考え方をしてほしい。
column27: We'd  like to be taught in such a way that we (come to) like studying.
column28: (f).　この問題について私と同じような考え方をする人は多くないでしょう。
column29: There  wouldn't be many people who think about this problem in the same way as I do.
column30: (g).　田村はその大臣をよく知っているような話し方をする。
column31: 1.  Tamura's talk sounds like he knows the minister well.  2. Tamura talks as if he knew that minister well.
column44:
(i) {Adjective い informal/Adjective な stem な/Vinformal} + (Noun の) +Vます方をする  
  ひどい負け方をする Lose in a terrible way
  ユニークなものも見方をする View things in a unique fashion
  よく分かる教え方をする Teach clearly (literally: in a way one can understand well)
(ii) Noun のような+(Nounの)+ Vます方をする  
  子供のようなものの言い方をする Talk like a child (literally: talk in a child like manner)
(iii) Vinformal ような+(Nounの)+ Vます方をする Adjectives rarely occur before ような
  人が感動するような話し方をする Speak in such a way that people are impressed

column2: A conjunction to indicate the speaker's assertion that a popular belief is not right.
column3: You would think that ~ but (that is not right)
column9: (ks).　日本人はみんな寿司が好き○○、そうではない。嫌いな人もいる。
column10: (ks).　日本人はみんな寿司が好きかと言うと、そうではない。嫌いな人もいる。
column11: You  would think that all the Japanese like sushi, but that is not true. Some  Japanese don't like it.
column12: (a).　がんは治らない病気かと言うと、そうではない。早期発見をすれば治ると言われている。
column13: You  would think that cancer is not curable, but that is not true. If it is detected  early it is said to be curable.
column14: (b).　日本に行って、二、三年住めば日本語が上手になるかと言うと、そうでもないようだ。かえって下手になることもある。
column15: You'd  think that if you went to Japan and lived there for a few years, your Japanese  would become good, but that doesn't seem to be true. On the contrary, your  Japanese may become worse than before.
column16: (c).　大学の時にいい成績の学生が社会で成功するかと言うと、必ずしもそうではないようだ。
column17: You'd  think that a college student with good grades would be successful in society,  but that doesn't always seem to be the case.
column18: (d).　毎日運動をすれば長生きをするかと言うと、そうでもなさそうだ。
column19: You'd  think that if you did exercise every day, you would live long, but that does  not seem to be true.
column20: (e).　日本語は難しいかと言うと、話したり聞いたりすることはそんなに難しくない。
column21: You'd  think that Japanese would be hard, but speaking and listening are not that  hard.
column22: (f).　ボストンでの車なしの生活が不便だったかと言うと、全然そうではなかったんです。
column23: You'd  think that my life without a car in Boston must have been inconvenient, but it  wasn't at all.
column44:
(i) ~{V/Adjective い} informal かと言うと、S  
  {話す /話した} かと言うと You would think that someone talks/talked but ~
  {高い /高かった} かと言うと You would think that something is/was expensive but ~
(ii) {Adjective な stem/ Noun} {Ø/だった} かと言うと、S  
  {静か /静かだった} かと言うと You would think that something is/was quiet but ~
  {先生/先生だった} かと言うと You would think that someone is/was a teacher but ~

column2: An action/state that is expressed in the subordinate clause is balanced by another action/state expressed in the main clause, or something/someone that is replaced by something/someone else.
column3: Instead of; instead; but (to make up for ~); so (to make up for ~); in place of
column9: (ksa).　昼間遊ぶ○○夜勉強するつもりだ。
column10: (ksa).　昼間遊ぶ代わりに夜勉強するつもりだ。
column11: I  am going to enjoy myself in the daytime, so /but (to make up for it) I will  study at night.
column12: (ksb).　山田さんにはちょっと余分に働いてもらった代わりに特別手当てを出した。
column13: Mr.  Yamada worked for us a bit extra, so / but (to make up-for it) we paid him  special compensation.
column14: (ksc).　前のアパートは設備が悪かった代わりに家賃が安かった。
column15: The  former apartment had bad facilities, so /but (to make up for it) the rent was  cheap.
column16: (ksd).　今朝は、コーヒーの代わりにココアを飲んだ。
column17: This  morning I drank cocoa instead of coffee.
column18: (a).　今日は図書館で勉強する代わりに寮の部屋で勉強した。
column19: Today  I didn't study in the library. Instead, I studied in my dorm room.
column20: (b).　私はトムに日本語を教えてあげた代わりに彼に英語を教えてもらった。
column21: I  taught Tom Japanese, so (to make up for it) he taught me English.
column22: (c).　高い長距離電話をかける代わりに、手紙をよく書いています。
column23: Instead  of making expensive long distance calls I often write letters.
column24: (d).　私のアパートは家賃が高い代わりに、駅に近くてとても便利です。
column25: My  apartment is expensive, but it is close to the station and very convenient.
column26: (e).　私達の日本語の先生は厳しい代わりに学生の面倒見がいい。
column27: Our  teacher is strict, but (instead) he takes good care of his students.
column28: (f).　大学の先生は給料が低い代わりに自由がある。
column29: College  professors' salaries are low, but (instead) they have freedom.
column30: (g).　父は体が弱い代わりに意志がとても強い。
column31: My  father is physically weak, but (instead) he has a very strong will.
column32: (h).　この辺は静かな代わりに、店も遠くて不便です。
column33: This  area is quiet, but (instead) it's inconvenient because the stores are far away.
column34: (i).　日本語の授業にいつもの山田先生の代わりに田中という新しい先生がいらっしゃった。
column35: To  our Japanese class came a new teacher Ms. Tanaka instead of our regular teacher  Ms. Yamada.
column44:
(i) {V/Adjective い} informal 代わりに  
  話す代わりに Instead of talking
  高い代わりに Instead of being expensive
(ii) Adjective な stem {な/だった}代わりに  
  静か{な/だった}代わりに Is/was quiet but (to make up for ~)
(iii) Noun {の/だった}代わりに  
  先生の代わりに In place of the teacher
  いい先生だった代わりに Someone was a good teacher, but (to make up for ~)

column2: A noun which expresses the idea "as a result of".
column3: As a result of; after; upon
column9: (ksa).　投票の○○、その提案は反対多数で否決された。
column10: (ksa).　投票の結果、その提案は反対多数で否決された。
column11: As  a result of the vote, the proposal was rejected by the majority's opposition.
column12: (ksb).　妻と相談した結果、家を買うことにした。
column13: After  my wife and I discussed it, we decided to buy a house.
column14: (a).　相談の結果、今回の旅行は延期することになった。
column15: After  discussion, it's been decided that the planned trip will be postponed.
column16: (b).　検査の結果、妻の体はどこにも異状がないことが分かった。
column17: As  a result of the examination, my wife was found to be healthy (literally: it was  found that there was no abnormality with my wife's body).
column18: (c).　調査の結果、新しい事実が発見された。
column19: As  a result of the investigation, new facts emerged.
column20: (d).　警察で調べた結果、原因は煙草の火の不始末と分かった。
column21: As  a result of the police investigation, it was determined that the cause (of the  fire) was the careless handling of a cigarette butt.
column22: (e).　特別のダイエットをした結果、十キロの減量に成功した。
column23: I've  succeeded in losing ten kilos as the result of a special diet.
column24: (f).　新しい教科書を使った結果、学生の成績が著しく伸びた。
column25: As  a result of using a new textbook, the students improved their performance  remarkably (literally: the performance of the students improved remarkably).
column26: (g).　ゴルフの個人指導を受けた結果、自分の問題点が明らかになった。
column27: Upon  taking a private golf lesson, my problems became clear.

column2: An adverb that indicates that something exceeds the speaker's and/or hearer's expectation to a considerable degree.
column3: Quite; rather; pretty
column9: (ks).　ここの寿司は、○○美味しいね。
column10: (ks).　ここの寿司は、結構美味しいね。
column11: The  sushi in this place is quite good, isn't it?
column12: (a).　この車は古いんだけど、結構よく走りますよ。
column13: This  car is old, but it runs quite well, you know.
column14: (b).　あの人は間抜けに見えるでしょう。でも、結構頭がいいんです。
column15: He  looks dumb, but he is quite sharp.
column16: (c).　四月だというのに、結構寒いね。
column17: It  is April, but it is rather cold, isn't it?
column18: (d).　小さい町なのに、結構いいレストランがあるね。
column19: There  are quite a few good restaurants in this small town, aren't there?
column20: (e).　この料理は量は少ないけど、結構胃にもたれるね。
column21: This  dish is small in quantity, but it is pretty heavy on the stomach.
column22: (f).　今日は日曜日なのに高速が結構混んでいるね。
column23: Today  is Sunday, but the highway is rather crowded, isn't it?
column24: (g).　父は楽天的な人でしたが、失職した時に結構悩んだようです。
column25: My  father was an optimist, but when he lost his job, I think he suffered quite a  bit.
column26: (h).　カラオケは初めてだったが、結構楽しかった。
column27: It  was my first karaoke, but it was rather enjoyable.
column46: 【Related Expression: 案外; いがいと; 割合】

column2: A demonstrative adjective which indicates a time or time period around the moment of speech.
column3: The last; this past; this; this coming

column10: (ksa).　秋山さんはこの春結婚します。
column11: Miss  Akiyama will marry (this spring / this coming spring).
column12: (ksb).　山下君はこの一週間授業を休んでいます。
column13: Yamashita  has been absent from class for the past (one) week.
column14: (a).　この間吉岡さんに会いました。

column16: (b).　このたびこの会の会員に加えていただきました。

column18: (c).　この際車を買おうか。
column19: Shall  we buy a car given this occasion?
column20: (d).　この辺で妥協したらどうですか。
column21: Why  don't we compromise now (literally: around this time)?

column23: This  summer I'm doing research on Japanese female writers.
column24: (f).　この一週間は忙しくて何もできないだろう。
column25: I'll  be busy this coming week and probably won't be able to do anything (else).
column26: (g).　この次はいつお目にかかれますか。
column27: When  could I meet you next?

column2: A demonstrative which refers to someone or something mentioned as an example in previous discourse.
column3: Such; like this

column10: (ks).　こうした問題はこの国では聞かれないようである。
column11: We  do not seem to hear about problems like this in this country.
column12: (a).　こうした行為がどのような結果を招くかは誰の目にも明らかだ。

column16: (c).　私はこうした話には耳を貸さないことにしている。
column17: I  make it a rule not to listen to such stories.

column2: A particle which emphasizes a word, phrase, or clause.
column3: The very ~; it is ~; that ~; only (when, after, because, etc.); in particular; precisely; definitely; [an italicized or underlined word]
column9: (ksa).　これ○○我々が探し求めていたものだ。
column10: (ksa).　これこそ我々が探し求めていたものだ。
column11: This  is the very thing that we've been looking for.
column12: (ksb).　Ａ：どうもすみませんでした。 Ｂ：いいえ、こちらこそすみませんでした。
column13: A:  I'm very sorry.           B: No, it's me  who should say that (literally: be sorry).
column14: (ksc).　一人でやってこそ勉強になるのだ。
column15: You can learn something only when you do it by yourself.
column16: (ksd).　君が正直に話してくれたからこそ問題は最小で済んだんだ。
column17: We could minimize the problem only because you explained  (literally: told) it to us honestly.
column18: (a).　A: 一体一週間も何をしていたんだ。 B: そう言う君こそ何をしていたんだ。
column19: A:  What on earth were you doing for a whole week?        B:  You say that but what were you doing?
column20: (b).　こんな時(に)こそ全員で力を合わせて問題を解決しなければならない。
column21: On  this kind of occasion, in particular, we all have to cooperate in order to  solve the problem.
column22: (c).　今年こそこの試験に通ってみせる。
column23: I will pass this exam definitely this year.
column24: (d).　それでこそ我々のリーダーだ。
column25: That is precisely the kind of behaviour we expect from our leader.
column26: (e).　ここにいてこそいい仕事も見つかるのだ。
column27: You can find a good job only by being here.
column28: (f).　親友だからこそこんなことまで君に言うんだよ。
column29: It's because you are my friend that I can tell you (even) such a thing.
column30: (g).　出来ないからこそ人より余計に練習しなければならないのだ。
column31: It’s precisely because you can’t do it that you have to practice more than others do.
column44:
(i) Noun (particle) こそ

column2: An auxiliary noun to express a command.

column10: (ksa).　発表は十五分以内で行うこと。

column12: (ksb).　プールサイドを走らないこと。

column17: Refrain  from whispering.
column18: (b).　先に必ずテープを聞くこと。

column20: (c).　辞書は見ないこと。

column22: (d).　裸足で歩き回らないこと。

column27: Wear  uniforms.

  話さないこと Should not speak

column2: A compound particle which indicates a means or a cause.
column3: By V-ing; because; result in; cause
column9: (ksa).　私は週末にゴルフをする○○気分転換を図っています。
column10: (ksa).　私は週末にゴルフをすることで気分転換を図っています。
column11: I  try to lift my spirits by playing golf on weekends.
column12: (ksb).　彼が仲裁の場に出ていったことで事態は余計にこじれた。
column13: His  appearance at the mediation scene complicated the situation even more.  (literally: The situation got even more complicated because he appeared at the  mediation scene.)
column14: (a).　私が十万円出すことで問題は解決した。
column15: The  problem was solved by my paying 100,000 yen.
column16: (b).　彼女はものを言わないことで私へ精一杯の抵抗を示しているのです。
column17: She  is demonstrating her utmost resistance to me by not talking.
column18: (c).　朝晩簡単な体操をするだけのことで素晴らしい健康が保てます。
column19: You  can maintain wonderful health just by taking simple exercise in the morning and  evening.
column20: (d).　私が参加することであなたに迷惑はかかりませんか。
column21: Wouldn't  my participation cause you trouble?
column22: (e).　彼のパーティーに行かなかったことで彼の気持ちを害したのでなければよいが。
column23: I  hope I didn't hurt his feelings because I didn't go to his party (literally: by  not having gone to his party).
column24: (f).　 私は英語が下手ことで時々損をしている。
column25: I  am sometimes put at a disadvantage because I am poor at English.
column26: (g).　この国では外国人であることで得をすることがある。
column27: In  this country there are times when you benefit for being a foreigner.
column44:
(i) Vinformal nonpast ことで Means
  行くことで By going
(ii) Sinformal ことで Cause
  {行く /行った} ことで Because someone will go/went
  {高い /高かった} ことで Because something is/was high
(iii) Adjective な stem なことで Exception
  便利なことで Because something is convenient
(iv) Noun であることで Exception
  女であることで Because someone is a woman
column46: 【Related Expression: から; ことにより; よって; ので; 為(に)】

column2: A phrase which indicates that an action or event leads to a certain situation or logical conclusion.
column3: End up (with); cause; come to mean that
column9: (ksa).　これ以上聞くのは彼を余計に苦しめる○○。
column10: (ksa).　これ以上聞くのは彼を余計に苦しめることになる。
column11: Asking  more than this will cause him to suffer too much.
column12: (ksb).　今これをしておかなかったら後で大変なことになる。
column13: If  we don't do this now, we will end up with an awful situation later.
column14: (ksc).　この手形が落ちなければ会社は倒産ということになる。
column15: If  we cannot have this draft cashed, our company will end up in bankruptcy.
column16: (ksd).　こんな結果になったということは我々の準備に手落ちがあったことになる。
column17: Ending  up with such a result means that there was something wrong with our  preparation.
column18: (kse).　今回何も起こらなかったということはこのシステムで大丈夫だということになる。
column19: The  fact that nothing happened this time means that the system is alright  (literally: the situation is alright with this system).
column20: (a).　今怠けていると試験の時ひどいことになるよ。
column21: If  you don't work now, you'll end up with a terrible situation when you take the  exam.
column22: (b).　そんなことをしたら二度と人前に出られないことになる。
column23: If  I / you do such a thing, I / you will end up not being able to appear in public  again.
column24: (c).　A社が百万円寄付してくれれば合計一千万円に達することになる。
column25: If  Company A donates one million yen, the total sum will become (literally: end up  with) ten million yen.
column26: (d).　すべてがうまくいけば来年卒業ということになります。
column27: If  everything goes well, (it means that) I will graduate next year.
column28: (e).　葉書が戻って来たということは彼はもうこの住所には住んでいないことになる。
column29: That  the postcard came back means that he doesn't live at this address any longer.
column30: (f).　これが一キロ二千円ということはこちらの方が高いということになる。
column31: That  this costs 2,000 yen a kilo means that this is more expensive.
column44:
(i) Vinformal nonpast ことになる  
  行くことになる End up going; lead someone to go
(ii) Adjective い informal nonpast ことになる  
  難しいことになる End up with a difficult situation
(iii) Adjective な stem なことになる  
  大変なことになる End up with an awful situation
(iv) Noun ということになる  
  失敗ということになる End up with a failure; come to mean that something is a failure
(v) Sinformal ことになる Exceptions: Adjective な stem だ→Adjective な stem or formation (vi); Nounだ→Nounである or formation (iv) or (vi)
  間違っていたことになる Come to mean that something was wrong
  大丈夫なことになる Come to mean that something is alright
  外国人であることになる Come to mean that someone is a foreigner
(vi) Sinformal ということになる  
  大丈夫だということになる Come to mean that something is alright

column2: A phrase which is used to present an event as the cause of something.
column3: Be due to the fact that; be caused by; be brought about by; be the result of; because
column9: (ksa).　今回の失敗は事前の話し合いが不十分だった○○。
column10: (ksa).　今回の失敗は事前の話し合いが不十分だったことによる。
column11: The  failure this time is the result of insufficient discussion beforehand  (literally: due to the fact that the preceding discussion was insufficient).
column12: (ksb).　進が非行に走ったの両親の愛情が不足していたことによる。
column13: Susumu's  delinquency was caused by his parents' lack of affection. (literally: The fact  that Susumu ran to juvenile delinquency is because his parents were not  affectionate enough with him.
column14: (a).　彼の現在の成功は平生の努力を怠らなかったことによる。
column15: His  present success is due to the fact that he worked hard every day (literally:  did not neglect daily effort).
column16: (b).　彼らの離婚は二人の価値観があまりに違っていたことによる。
column17: Their  divorce was caused by the fact that their value systems were very different.
column18: (c).　彼が負けたのは勝ちを焦りすぎたことによる。
column19: His  loss is due to the fact that he tried to win quickly.
column20: (d).　彼の才能がこれ程までに開発されたのは鈴木氏に師事したことによる。
column21: That  his talent was developed to this degree is due to the fact that he studied with  Mr. Suzuki.
column44:
Sinformal ことによる Exceptions: Adjective な stem なことによる; Noun であることによる
  家賃が高いことによる Because the rent is expensive
  表現が不正確なことによる Because the expression is inaccurate
  母が日本人であることによる Because one’s mother is Japanese

column46: 【Related Expression: からだ; ためだ】

column2: A phrase which expresses the idea that there is no need to do something or that there is no possibility of doing something.
column3: There is no need to; not necessary; there is no possibility that; there is no chance to
column9: (ksa).　あんな男の言うことを聞く○○。
column10: (ksb).　あんな男の言うことを聞くことはない。
column11: There's  no need to listen to a man like that.
column12: (ksb).　彼女が今日の会議を忘れることはないと思います。
column13: I  think that there is no possibility that she will forget today's meeting.
column14: (a).　あんな奴に親切にしてやることはない。
column15: There  is no need to be kind to a guy like that.
column16: (b).　何もそんなに慌てることはない。
column17: There  is no need at all to be in such a hurry.
column18: (c).　君が来ることはないと思います。

column21: 1.  There will probably be no need for him to take the trouble to go out there.       2. There is no possibility that he will  go out there.

column24: (f).　多分私が教えることはないと思います。

Vinformal nonpast ことはない Affirmation
  行くことはない There’s no need to go/there is no possibility that someone will go

column2: A continuative form of an い-type adjective.
column3: And; so
column9: (ksa).　加奈子の性格は明る○○、無邪気だった。
column10: (ksa).　加奈子の性格は明るく、無邪気だった。
column11: Kanako's  personality was cheerful and innocent.
column12: (ksb).　せっかく講演をしに行ったのに、聴衆が少なく、がっかりした。
column13: I  went all the way to give a lecture, but the audience was so small that I felt  discouraged.

column16: (b).　トムの東京のアパートの部屋は暗く、狭い。
column17: Tom's  apartment room in Tokyo is dark and small.
column18: (c).　バッハの音楽は歯切れがよく、幾何学的だ。

column21: The  New York Times is high in quality and has many subscribers.

column23: World  peace is hard to achieve and hard to maintain.
column24: (f).　あの哲学者の思想は分かりやすく、文章も簡潔だ。

column26: (g).　去年の冬は雪が多く、車の運転が大変だった。

column28: (h).　私は失敗が恐ろしく、新しいことが何も出来ない。

column2: A particle which is used to express the degree of a state.
column3: To the extent that; so ~ that ~ (almost) ~; at least; the only ~; rather than ~
column9: (ksa).　私達は一歩も歩けない○○疲れていた。

column11: We  were so tired that we couldn't even take a step. (literally: We were tired to  the extent that we couldn't even walk one step.)
column12: (ksb).　今晩は暖かいのでストーブが要らないくらいだ。
column13: It  is so warm this evening that we (almost) don't need a heater.
column14: (ksc).　山田さんくらいよく物を忘れる人はいない。
column15: There's  no one who is as forgetful as Yamada (literally: who forgets things as much as  Yamada does).
column16: (ksd).　私は料理は下手ですが、ご飯くらい（は）炊けます。
column17: I  am a poor cook (literally: bad at cooking), but I can at least cook rice.
column18: (kse).　今この仕事が出来るのは彼くらいのものだ。

column20: (ksf).　そんなことをするくらいなら死んだ方がましだ。
column21: I  would rather die than do such a thing.
column22: (a).　その家は直しようがないくらい傷んでいた。
column23: That  house was so damaged that it couldn't be repaired. (literally: That house was  damaged to the extent that it couldn't be repaired.)
column24: (b).　次郎はひどく酔っていて立っていられないくらいだった。
column25: Jiro  was so drunk that he couldn't hold himself upright.
column26: (c).　こんな本、十ドルでもまだ高いくらいだ。
column27: Even  ten dollars would still be too expensive for a book like this.
column28: (d).　内田さんくらいかわいそうな人はいない。
column29: This  is no one who is as pitiful as Uchida.
column30: (e).　あの時くらい苦しかった時はない。
column31: I  have never suffered as much as I did that time.
column32: (f).　信頼していた人に裏切られる（こと）くらい辛いことはない。
column33: There  is nothing as painful as being betrayed by someone you have trusted.
column34: (g).　いくら安い所でもシャワーくらい付いているでしょう。
column35: Even  though it is a cheap place, there should at least be a shower.
column36: (h).　そんな物に二万円も出すのはあなたくらいのものですよ。
column37: You  are the only person who would pay as much as 20,000 yen for such a thing.
column38: (i).　あんな男の下で働くくらいなら乞食になった方がましだ。
column39: I  would rather be a beggar than work under such a man.
column44:
(i) SinformalくらいThe same as relative connection rules
泳げるくらいTo the extent that one can swim
(先生も) 出来なかったくらいTo the extent that (even our teacher) couldn’t do it
恐ろしいくらいTo the extend that (I) am frightened
気の毒なくらいTo the extent that (i) feel sorry
(ii) Nounくらい
山田さんくらいTo Yamada’s degree

column2: A conjunction which expresses the speaker's contempt, anger, or disagreement about someone's action, behaviour, or state.
column3: Although; in spite of the fact that; and yet; but
column9: (ksa).　山田さんは日本人の○○あまり漢字を知らない。
column10: (ksa).　山田さんは日本人のくせにあまり漢字を知らない。
column11: Although  Mr. Yamada is Japanese, he doesn't know many kanji.
column12: (ksb).　山内はよく知っているくせに何も教えてくれない。
column13: In  spite of the fact that Yamauchi knows a lot about it, he doesn't tell me  anything.
column14: (a).　彼は大学生のくせに漫画ばかり読んでいる。
column15: Although  he is a college student, all he does is read comics.
column16: (b).　良子はまだ学生のくせに高いマンションに住んでいる。
column17: Although  Yoshiko is still a student, she lives in an expensive condominium.
column18: (c).　隆司は下手なくせに私とテニスをしたがる。
column19: Takashi  is a bad (tennis) player, and yet he wants to play with me.
column20: (d).　怖いくせに無理するなよ。
column21: You  are afraid. Don't pretend to be strong.
column22: (e).　孝男はお金もないくせに外車を欲しがっている。
column23: Takao  doesn't have money, and yet he wants a foreign car.
column24: (f).　吉田は前は私を見ても挨拶もしなかったくせに、私が部長になった途端に急に愛想がよくなった。
column25: Before  (the time I became a division chief), Yoshida never greeted me when he saw me, but he suddenly became friendly  when I became a division chief.
column26: (g).　昨日まで見習いだったくせに大きな口をきくな。
column27: Don't  talk big! You were only a trainee until yesterday!
column44:
(i) Nounのくせに
子供のくせにAlthough ~ is a child
(ii) {V/Adjective い} informalくせに
{出来る/出来た} くせにAlthough ~ can/could
{弱い/弱かった} くせにAlthough ~ is/was weak
(iii) Adjective な stem{な / だった} くせに
{下手な / 下手 だった} くせにAlthough ~ is/was bad at something

column2: There is no point in going as far as to do something.
column3: Not necessary (to bother) to; do not need (to go as far as) to; do not have to
column9: (ksa).　これは簡単な計算だから計算器を使う○○。
column10: (ksa).　これは簡単な計算だから計算器を使うまでもない。
column11: This  is a simple calculation, so it is not necessary (to bother) to use a  calculator.
column12: (ksb).　言うまでもなくジョージ・ワシントンはアメリカの初代大統領だ。
column13: Needless  to say, George Washington was the first president of the United States.
column14: (a).　彼がみんなに尊敬されたのは言うまでもない。
column15: It  goes without saying that he was respected by everybody.
column16: (b).　大した用事じゃないからあなたがわざわざ行くまでもないでしょう。
column17: It  is not important business, so it is probably not necessary for you to (take the  trouble to) get there.
column18: (c).　行けば分かることですから電話して聞くまでもありません。
column19: We  can find out when we get there, so we don't need to call and about it.
column20: (d).　今更申すまでもありませんが、山中先生はこの分野では指導的な立場にあるお方です。
column21: Needless  to say (now), Professor Yamanaka is a leading figure in this field.
column22: (e).　それは説明するまでもなく明らかなことだ。
column23: It  is so obvious that no explanation is necessary.
column24: (f).　待つまでもなく妻は買い物から帰ってきた。
column25: My  wife came back from shopping without my having to wait for her.
column44:
Vinformal nonpastまでもない
話すまでもないNot necessary (to bother) to talk
column46: 【Related Expression: 必要はない; ほどのこともない; には及ばない】

column2: An auxiliary which expresses the speaker's negative volition or conjecture.
column3: Will not; will probably not; be probably not
column9: (ksa).　もう橋本には何も頼む○○。
column10: (ksa).　もう橋本には何も頼むまい。
column11: I  will not ask any more favours of Hashimoto.
column12: (ksb).　これは恐らく誰も気が付くまい。
column13: Probably  no one will notice this.
column14: (ksc).　参加者はそれほど多くはあるまい。
column15: There  probably won't be many participants.
column16: (ksd).　この教え方はあまり効果的ではあるまい。
column17: This  teaching method is probably not very effective.
column18: (kse).　これは何かの間違いではあるまいか。
column19: I  have a feeling that this is some kind of mistake. (literally: Is this not some  kind of mistake?)
column20: (a).　清のパーティーにはもう行くまい。
column21: I  will not go to Kiyoshi's parties any more.
column22: (b).　日本へ行こうか行くまいか迷った。
column23: I  couldn't decide whether I should go to Japan or not.
column24: (c).　彼は多分誰の言うことも聞くまい。
column25: He  probably won't listen to anyone.
column26: (d).　それは今我々には必要ではあるまい。
column27: It  is probably not necessary for us now.
column28: (e).　この問題はこの学校の学生にはそれほど難しくはあるまい。
column29: This  problem is probably not very difficult for these students.
column30: (f).　ジョージが真相を知っているのではあるまいか。
column31: I  have a feeling that George knows the truth.
column44:
(i) Vinformal nonpastまい
行くまい(I) will not go; probably won’t go
教えるまい(I) will not teach; probably won’t teach
(ii) Adjective い stemくはあるまい
高くはあるまいSomething is probably not expensive
(iii) {Adjective な stem/Noun}ではあるまい
静かではあるまいSomething is probably not quiet
先生ではあるまいSomeone is probably not a teacher
column45: Auxiliary (used in writing and formal speech only)

column2: An adverb that indicates the speaker's strong belief that something is not expected to (have) become a reality.
column3: Incredible; never thought; never dreamed; surely not; impossible; don't tell me that ~; not at all likely; absolutely not.
column9: (ksa).　○○美智子があんな男と結婚するとは思わなかった。
column10: (ksa).　まさか美智子があんな男と結婚するとは思わなかった。
column11: I  never dreamed that Michiko would marry that kind of a guy.
column12: (ksb).　まさかあたしの誕生日を忘れたんじゃないでしょうね。
column13: Don't  tell me that you forgot my birthday!
column14: (ksc).　まさか彼がこんな寒い日に来るはずはないですよ。
column15: Surely  he won't show up on such a cold day!
column16: (ksd).　最近父から手紙が来ないけれど、まさか具合が悪いのではあるまい。
column17: Lately  I haven't heard from my father, but God forbid that he might be ill.
column18: (kse).　Ａ：七十のおじいさんが高校に入ったんだって。 Ｂ：まさか。
column19: A:  I heard that an old man of 70 entered a high school.   B: Incredible!
column20: (a).　まさか自分が交通事故に巻き込まれるとは思いませんでしたよ。
column21: I  never thought that I would be involved in a traffic accident.
column22: (b).　まさか司法試験に一度でパス出来るとは考えてもいなかった。
column23: I  never dreamed that I could pass the bar examination on my first attempt.
column24: (c).　青い顔をしているけど、まさか病気じゃないでしょうね。
column25: You  look pale. Are you sure you are not ill?
column26: (d).　まさかこんな高いダイヤモンドの指輪を買ってくれたんじゃないでしょうね。
column27: I  don't believe that you brought me such an expensive diamond ring!
column28: (e).　まさかあんないい人が人を殺すなんてあるはずがない。
column29: Don't  tell me a good person like that killed someone.
column30: (f).　まさか彼が日本語の先生になるとは考えてもみなかった。
column31: I  never thought that he would become a Japanese language teacher.
column32: (g).　まさかあの人がそんなことを言うはずはないでしょ。
column33: It's  not at all likely that she has said such a thing!
column34: (h).　もう五月なのだから、まさか雪は降るまい。
column35: Since  it is May it is very unlikely that it will snow.
column36: (i).　母は入院中だから、まさか私の結婚式に出席するわけにはいくまい。
column37: Because  my mother is in the hospital right now, it is impossible to expect her to  attend my wedding.
column38: (j).　A: スミスさんは日本語を一年しか勉強していないのに、ペラペラですよ。 B: まさか。
column39: A:  Smith has studied Japanese for only one year, but he is fluent, you know.      B: Impossible!
column44:
(i) まさかSとは{思わなかった/考えてもみなかった}
まさか雪が降るとは{思わなかった/考えてもみなかった}{I didn’t believe/I never though} that it would snow
(ii) まさかS{んじゃ/のでは} ないだろうね
まさか会社を辞める{んじゃ/のでは}ないだろうねDon’t tell me that you are going to quit the company
(iii) まさかSはずがない
まさか四月に雪が降るはずがないIt is not at all likely that it will snow in April
(iv) まさかSまい
まさか雪は降るまいDon’t tell me it’s going to snow

column2: A phrase indicating that although someone/something (or some situation) is not satisfactory it is better than someone/something else.
column3: Better; less objectionable; preferable; might as well ~
column9: (ksa).　こんな給料をもらう（くらい）なら辞めた方が○○。
column10: (ksa).　こんな給料をもらう（くらい）なら辞めた方がましだ。
column11: If  this is the salary, it would be better to quit.
column12: (ksb).　今度の日本語の先生は前の先生よりずっとましだ。
column13: This  new Japanese teacher is much better than the former teacher.
column14: (ksc).　もう少しましなコーヒーはありませんか。
column15: Isn't  there coffee that's a bit better?
column16: (a).　こんな大学に入るくらいなら、仕事をした方がましだ。
column17: I  might as well work as enter such a college.
column18: (b).　こんな苦しい生活をするくらいなら、死んだ方がましだ。
column19: It  is better to die than to lead such a life.
column20: (c).　学校へ行くくらいなら家でテレビでも見ていた方がましだ。
column21: It's  better to watch TV at home rather than going to school.
column22: (d).　こんな不味いご飯を食べるくらいなら何も食べない方がいい。
column23: It's  better not to eat anything rather than eating such an untasteful meal.
column24: (e).　あのレストランよりこのレストランの方がましだ。
column25: This  restaurant is better than that restaurant over there.
column26: (f).　ここの夏も暑いですが、東京の夏よりましですね。
column27: Summer  here is hot, too, but it's better than summer in Tokyo.
column28: (g).　僕の車もとても古いけど、君のよりましだ。
column29: My  car is also very old, but it is better than yours.
column30: (h).　給料は二万円でも、ないよりましだ。
column31: Although  the salary is just 20,000 yen it's better than nothing.
column32: (i).　お宅は狭いと言っても私の家に比べたらずっとましですよ。
column33: You  say your house is small, but it is much better than our house, you know.
column34: (j).　もう少しましな人間になろうと思っています。
column35: I  am thinking of becoming a slightly better person.
column36: (k).　このホテルはひどいですね。この辺にもう少しましなホテルはないんでしょうか。
column37: This  hotel is awful. Isn't there a slightly better hotel around here?

column2: A conjunction which connects two choices or possibilities expressed by noun phrases or sentences.
column3: Or; either ~ or ~
column9: (ksa).　現金（か）、○○小切手でお払い下さい。
column10: (ksa).　現金（か）、または小切手でお払い下さい。

column18: (b).　三年以下の懲役（か）、または百万円以下の罰金。

column20: (c).　昼は仕事があるから、夜間コースを取るか、または家庭教師を探すしかない。

column22: (d).　二週間前に出したはずの手紙がまだ先方に着いていない。私の秘書が出し忘れたか、または郵便局が間違えたのだろう。
column23: A  letter that I assumed was mailed two weeks ago has not reached the addressee  yet. It is probably that my secretary forgot to mail it or that the post office  made a mistake.
column44:
(i) Noun (か)、またはNoun
日本語(か)、または語英語Either Japanese or English

手紙を書くか、または電話をするEither write a letter or make a phone call

column2: A suffix which represents an ordinal number.

Number+Counter目
四人目The fourth (person)

column2: A suffix which forms a compound that means a side of X, or an aspect of X.
column3: (on) the side of; (from) the aspect of; (from) the standpoint/viewpoint of; in terms of
column9: (ks).　彼か学業○○では優秀だが、精神○○に少し弱さがあるようだ。
column10: (ks).　彼か学業面では優秀だが、精神面に少し弱さがあるようだ。

column12: (a).　この食堂は衛生面によく気を配っている。
column13: This  restaurant pays close attention to hygiene (literally: the hygienic aspect).
column14: (b).　藤田さんは技術面からのみものを見る傾向がある。
column15: Mr.  Fujita tends to view things from the technical standpoint alone.
column16: (c).　ここの土地所有者は税金面で優遇措置を受けている。
column17: The  land owners here receive favourable treatment in terms of tax.
column18: (d).　あの候補者の演説は政策面での説得力に欠ける。
column19: That candidate's speech is not convincing (literally: lacks persuasive power) from the standpoint of policy.
column20: (e).　彼女は日本へ行っても語学面は心配しなくてもいい。
column21: She  does not need to worry about language (literally: the aspect of language) when  she goes to Japan

column23: This  car was highly regarded in terms of performance.
column44:
Noun面
運営面The aspect of operation; the standpoint of operation

column2: The speaker's strong determination to achieve something for others to see.
column3: Can manage to; will definitely do; am determined to
column9: (ks).　僕は小説を書いて、芥川賞を取って○○。

column16: (c).　三百ページの本を一時間で読んでみせるぞ。

column18: (d).　今年こそは修士論文を書き上げてみせる。

column20: (e).　一男は百メートルを十一秒で走ってみせた。
column21: Kazuo  managed to run 100 meters in 11 seconds.
column44:
Vてみせる(Group 2)
読んでみせるI will definitely read it/I will show you how to read it

column2: A particle which implies that something else is also (not) the case.

column9: (ksa).　吉岡さんは今年七十歳だが、毎日一キロ走る。時々泳ぎ○○する。

column17: Mr.  Okuda is a lawyer and also a novelist.
column18: (kse).　由利子は最近廊下ですれ違っても見向きもしない。

column20: (a).　猿だっておかしければ笑いもするでしょう。
column21: Apes also laugh if something is funny, right?
column22: (b).　健一は新婚早々三日も家を空けたが、和代は泣かなかった。そして、怒りもしなかった。
column23: Ken'ichi didn't go home for three days right after their marriage, but Kazuyo didn't cry. She didn't get mad, either.

column25: That apartment is not convenient and not inexpensive, either.
column26: (d).　周遊券は便利な上、経済的でもある。

column30: (f).　安くもないのに、そうしてそんなものを買うんですか。
column31: Why are you going to buy a thing like that which is not even cheap?
column44:
(i) Vますもする/もしない
読みもするAlso read
読みもしないDo not read, either; do not even read
(ii) Adjective い stemくもある/くもない
安くもあるSomething is also cheap
安くもないSomething is not cheap, either; something is not even cheap
(iii) {Adjective な stem/Noun}でもある/でもない
便利でもあるSomething is also convenient
便利でもないSomething is not convenient, either; something is not even convenient
先生でもあるSomeone is also a teacher
先生でもないSomeone is not a teacher, either; someone is not even a teacher

column2: A structure which expresses the idea that a certain amount of something is sufficient to do something.
column3: Be enough to/for; if ~ at least; if ~ as much/many as ~, it will be enough to
column9: (ks).　この美術館は三時間○○あれ○○全部見られる。

column11: Three  hours are enough to see everything in this art museum. (literally: If you have  as many as three hours, you can see everything in this art museum.)
column12: (a).　二万円も持って行けば足りるでしょう。
column13: 20,000  yen will probably be enough. (literally: If you take as much as 20,000 yen with  you, it will probably be sufficient.)
column14: (b).　ビールは二ダースも買っておけば大丈夫だ。

column16: (c).　一週間もすれば歩けるようになります。

column18: (d).　二、三回も聞けば大体分かる。

column44:
Number+CounterもVconditional
五人も来ればIf five people come, it will be enough to ~

column44:
(i) VますもVます もする/しない
読みも書きもするBoth read and write
読みも書きもしないNeither read nor write
Vますも{し/するし/すれば} Vますもする
読みも{し/するし/すれば}書きもするRead and also write
Vますも{せず/しないし/しなければ} Vますもしない
読みも{せず/しないし/しなければ}書きもしないDo not read and do not write, either
(ii) VnounもVnounもする/しない
料理も掃除もするBoth cook and clean
料理も掃除もしないNeither cook nor clean
Nounも{し/するし/すれば}Nounもする
料理も{し/するし/すれば}掃除もするCook and also clean
Nounも{せず/しないし/しなければ}Nounもしない
料理も{せず/しないし/しなければ}掃除もしないDoes not cook and does not clean, either
(iii) Adjective い stemくもAdjective い stemくもある/ない
うれしくも悲しくもあるBoth happy and sad
うれしくも悲しくもないNeither happy nor sad
Adjective い stemくも{なく/ないし/なければ} Adjective い stemくもない
うれしくも{なく/ないし/なければ}悲しくもないNot happy and not sad, either
(iv) {Adjective な stem/Noun}でも{Adjective な stem/Noun}でもある/ない
便利でも経済的でもあるBoth convenient and economical
便利でも経済的でもないNeither convenient nor economical
{Adjective な stem/Noun}でも{あり/あるし/あれば}{Adjective な stem/Noun}でもある
便利でも{あり/あるし/あれば}経済的でもあるConvenient and also economical
{Adjective な stem/Noun}でも{なく/ないし/なければ}{Adjective な stem/Noun}でもない
便利でも{なく/ないし/なければ}経済的でもないNot convenient and not economical, either

column2: A disjunctive conjunction used normally in written Japanese with the meaning of 'although'.

column2: A phrase that is used to express insurmountable psychological or physical feelings.
