column2: A phrase that represents emotions the speaker/writer cannot control or sensations/situations he/she cannot bear.
column3: Cannot help ~ing; cannot stop feeling; (so ~ and) cannot control ~; so ~ and ~ cannot bare it; so; unbearably
column9: (ksa).　会社の理不尽なリストラに腹が立っ○○。
column10: (ksa).　会社の理不尽なリストラに腹が立って仕方がない。
column11: I'm so mad at the company's unreasonable restructuring (i.e., laying off workers) (and cannot control my anger).
column12: (ksb).　久しぶりに妻や子供たちに会えるので嬉しくて仕方がない。
column13: Because I get to see my wife and children for the ﬁrst time in a long while, I am so happy (and can hardly control my emotion).
column14: (ksc).　ここは何もすることがないので退屈で仕方がない。
column15: Because I have nothing to do here, I'm unbearably bored.
column16: (a).　アンディーがアメリカに帰ってまだ二日しか経っていないのに、寂しくて仕方がない。
column17: Although it's been only two days since Andy went back to America, I miss him so much (literally: I'm so lonely and can hardly control my emotion).
column18: (b).　こんなすばらしい建物が取り壊されるのかと思うと残念で仕方がない
column19: I feel so bad when I think that such a wonderful building is going to be demolished.
column20: (c).　ボーイフレンドが一年の日本留学を終えて来週帰ってくる。早く会いたくて仕方がない。
column21: My boyfriend is coming back next week after finishing his year  of study in Japan. I'm dying to see him (literally: I want to see him soon so  much)!
column22: (d).　悪い風邪を引いたらしい。咳が出て仕方がない。
column23: I seem to have a bad cold. I cannot control my coughing.
column24: (e).　ここは空港のすぐ近くなので飛行機の音がうるさくて仕方がない。
column25: Because this place is close to an airport, the noise from the  airplanes is unbearable.
column26: (f).　この参考書は索引が不完全なので使いにくくて仕方がない。
column27: Because this reference book has an incomplete index, it is so  hard to use.
column28: (g).　私のうちは近くにスーパーもコンビニもないので不便で仕方がない。
column29: Because there is neither a supermarket nor a convenience store  near my house, it is unbearably inconvenient.
column30: (h).　先週、学会で会った女性が気になって仕方がない。
column31: I cannot stop thinking about the woman I met at the academic  conference last week.
column32: (i).　母親になった途端に自分の子供がよその子供より可愛く思えて仕方がない。
column33: As soon as I became a mother, I couldn't help thinking that my  child was cuter than other children.
column44:
(i) Verbて仕方がない
喉が乾いて仕方がない(I) am so thirsty (and cannot bear it)
(ii) Adjectiveいstemくて仕方がない
悲しくて仕方がない(I) am so sad (and can hardly control (my) emotion)
(iii) Adjectiveなで仕方がない
いやで仕方がない(I) dislike it so much (and (I)) can hardly control (my) emotion
column46: 【Related Expression: てならない; て堪らない; (とい)ったらない】

column2: A phrase that is used when someone cannot be doing something or be in some state due to a given situation.
column3: Cannot/shouldn’t be ~ing; cannot/shouldn’t keep ~ing; cannot/shouldn’t (stay/remain/etc.); cannot/shouldn’t waste time ~ing; cannot afford to; cannot help ~ing
column9: (ksa).　将来のことを考えると、いつまでもこんな仕事をし○○。
column10: (ksa).　将来のことを考えると、いつまでもこんな仕事をしてはいられない。
column11: When I think about the future, (I realise) I can't keep doing this kind of work forever.
column12: (ksb).　彼女があまりにも自分勝手だったので、一言言わないではいられなかった。
column13: Because she was acting so selﬁshly, I couldn't resist saying something to her.
column14: (ksc).　彼が好きだと気づいた時から、もうただの友達ではいられなくなった。
column15: Once I realised that I loved him, I couldn't be just a friend anymore.
column16: (a).　もうすぐ飛行機が出るのでぐずぐずしてはいられない。
column17: My plane is departing soon, so I cannot afford to dawdle.
column18: (b).　やることがたくさんあるのでパーティーなんかに行ってはいられない。
column19: I have so many things to do that I can't spend my time going to parties.
column20: (c).　自分にも同じ口癖があるので人のことを笑ってはいられない。
column21: I have the same speech habits, so I can't afford to laugh at  other people.
column22: (d).　あの教え方を見ていると時代錯誤を感じないではいられない。
column23: When I see that teaching method, I can't help thinking how  outdated it is.
column24: (e).　忙しい時代に生まれ、時間に追われがちな今の子供たちを案じないではいられない。
column25: I cannot help being concerned about today's children, who were  born in such a busy age and who tend to be pressed for time.
column26: (f).　私は一日も本なしではいられない。
column27: I can't go even a day without books.
column28: (g).　よその国の事件とは言え、同じようなことはこの国でも起きる可能性がある。とても無関心ではいられない。
column29: Although that incident was in another country, it could happen  in this country, too. I simply can't remain indifferent.
column30: (h).　彼女は日本中のみんなに期待されているので、もう普通の選手ではいられなくなった。
column31: With Japan's hopes riding on her, she can no longer be just an  ordinary player.
column32: (i).　地球環境は急速に悪化している。いつまでもこのままではいられない。
column33: The earth's environment is worsening rapidly. We just can't  continue to do nothing.
column44:
(i) Verbてはいられない
寝てはいられないCannot stay in bed
(ii) Vnegativeではいられない
話さないではいられないCannot keep from talking
(iii) {Adjectiveなstem/ Noun}ではいられない
平静ではいられないCannot remain calm
いつまでも子供ではいられないCannot be a child forever
column46: 【Related Expression: ずにはいられない; わけにはいかない】

column2: A phrase that introduces a reason when the speaker/writer considers it natural that someone does something or is in some state, or that something takes place for that reason.
column3: Because ~, ~ as expected; because ~, naturally ~; because
column9: (ksa).　ボーナス後の連休○○、観光地はどこも人でいっぱいだ。
column10: (ksa).　ボーナス後の連休とあって、観光地はどこも人でいっぱいだ。
column11: Because this is the series of holidays after the bonus season, (not surprisingly) all the tourist spots are crowded.
column12: (ksb).　夏休みが始まったとあって、子供たちはみんな嬉しそうだ。
column13: Summer vacation has begun, so the children all look happy.
column14: (a).　優勝を争うチーム同士の対決とあって、スタジアムは超満員だ。
column15: Because this is the match between the teams competing for the championship, the stadium is packed beyond capacity.
column16: (b).　人気作家のサイン会とあって、本屋にはサインを求める人たちが長い列を作った。
column17: Because it was the autograph session for a popular writer, people (who wanted his autograph) made a long line at the bookstore.
column18: (c).　レポートの締め切りがあさってとあって、学生たちはみんな焦っている。
column19: Because the deadline for the paper is the day after tomorrow, the students are all panicking.
column20: (d).　掃除が終わったらお菓子がもらえるとあって、子供たちは一生懸命手伝っている。
column21: Because they know they'll get sweets after they finish  cleaning, the children are doing their very best to help out.
column22: (e).　中途半端な訓練では実社会で通用しないとあって、この語学学校の指導は非常に厳しい。
column23: Because slapdash training does not help students function in  the real world, the teaching at this language institution is very strict.
column24: (f).　この社会人プログラムは、科目を低額で聴講できるだけでなく、自習室や図書館も自由に利用できるとあって、かなりの応募があります。
column25: Because this program for professionals not only allows students  to audit courses cheaply but lets them use study rooms and the library freely,  we receive quite a few applications.
column44:
(i) NPとあって
病気とあってBecause someone is ill
(ii) Sinformalとあってだ after Adjectiveなstem and Noun is omitted
韓国語ができるとあってBecause someone can speak Korean
タクシーの方が安いとあってBecause a taxi is cheaper
ノートパソコンの方が便利とあってBecause a laptop computer is more convenient
父親が医者とあってBecause someone’s father is a doctor
column45: Phrase (usually used in formal writing and formal speech)

column2: A conditional phrase that indirectly presents a factual situation as a reason.
column3: If it is true that; if it is the case that; if; because; since
column9: (ksa).　社長の頼み○○断るわけにはいかない。
column10: (ksa).　社長の頼みとあっては断るわけにはいかない。
column11: If (it's true that) it's a favour for the president, I can't say no.
column12: (ksb).　全商品が3割引きで買えるとあっては、遠方からわざわざ人が買いに来るのもうなずける。
column13: If (it's true that) you can buy everything at 30% off, I understand why people come from far away to shop (here).
column14: (a).　この大学が他の大学に統合されるのは残念だが、国の方針とあっては致し方ない。
column15: It is a pity that this university is going to be integrated into another university, but if that's the national policy, it cannot be helped.
column16: (b).　ブラジル・ドイツ戦のすぐ後とあっては国内チーム同士の試合が物足りなく感じられたのも仕方がない。
column17: Because it came right after the game between Brazil and Germany, it was inevitable that people did not feel the game between the domestic teams was very exciting.
column18: (c).　皆が多忙な身とあっては30人以上の家族が集まれるのはクリスマスの休みしかない。
column19: Since everyone is so busy, Christmas vacation is the only time our family of more than 30 can get together.
column20: (d).　スカイダイビングがここサイパンで楽しめるとあっては、挑戦してみない手はない。
column21: If it's true that we can enjoy skydiving here in Saipan,  there's no reason not to try it.
column22: (e).　どんなに短い作文でも、他の人に読まれ、コメントがつくとあっては、書く時の真剣味が増す。
column23: No matter how short your composition is, if it is read by  others and they make comments, it makes you think more seriously when you  write.
column24: (f).　役人の飲食費に税金が使われたとあっては、誰もが腹立たしく思うのは当たり前だ。しかも、そのことが明るみに出そうになると、今度は圧力をかけて「口封じ」をやったとあっては、もう救いようがない。
column25: If tax money was used to pay for government officials' dining  and drinking, of course people would be angry. But there's no hope if the  ofﬁcials pressured those involved to keep their mouths shut when the practice  was about to be exposed.
column44:
(i) NPとあっては
病気とあってはIf it’s true that someone is ill
(ii) Sinformalとあってはだ after Adjectiveなstem and Noun is omitted
由美も行くとあってはIf it’s true that Yumi is going, too
タクシーの方が安いとあってはIf it’s true that a taxi is cheaper
バスの方が便利とあってはIf it’s true that the bus is more convenient
締め切りが今週末とあってはIf it’s the case that the deadline is the end of this week
column46: 【Related Expression: (の)であれば; (の)なら; (の)だから; (な)ので】

column2: A phrase that indicates that someone does something in order to convey something or in such a way that someone is convinced that something is the case.
column3: As if; as if to say that; as if ~ were convinced that; as if ~ believed that; as if ~ decided that
column9: (ksa).　悟は「黙ってついてこい」○○先に立って歩き出した。
column10: (ksa).　悟は「黙ってついてこい」とばかりに先に立って歩き出した。
column11: Satoru started off (literally: began to walk ahead) as if to say: "Don't say anything and follow me."
column12: (ksb).　課長は余計な質問はするなとばかりに私をにらみつけた。
column13: My section chief glared at me as if to tell me not to ask any unnecessary questions.
column14: (ksc).　霧が晴れたので、私は今がチャンスとばかりに写真を撮りまくった。
column15: The fog had cleared, so I took pictures furiously, as if it were my only chance.
column16: (ksd).　竹本はこの時とばかりに日頃の不満を吐き出した。
column17: Takemoto vented his long-held complaints as if he were convinced this was the time (to do so).
column18: (a).　彼女は「えい！」とばかりに侵入者を投げ飛ばした。
column19: She threw off (literally: ﬂung) the intruder with a yell (literally: as if yelling, "Ei.!").
column20: (b).　庭園の花たちは早く撮ってとばかりに美しく咲いていました。
column21: The ﬂowers in the garden were blooming beautifully, as if they  wanted us to take their pictures.
column22: (c).　思い立ったが吉日とばかりにエアロビクスを始めました。
column23: I began aerobics believing that the day you think of something  is an auspicious day to start it.
column24: (d).　新鮮な魚を食べられるのは今日が最後とばかりに、刺身を食べられるだけ食べた。
column25: I ate as much sashimi as I could, as if I were convinced it was  the last day I could eat fresh ﬁsh.
column26: (e).　守は心の洗濯とばかりに一週間の旅行に出かけた。
column27: Mamoru left for a one-week trip, seemingly convinced that it  would refresh his mind.
column28: (f).　彼らはここぞとばかりに自分たちの給料の安さを訴えた。
column29: Seeming to have decided that this was a great opportunity, they  protested that their wages were low.
column44:
(i) Direct Quotationとばかりに
「それ！」とばかりにAs if to say, “there you go!”
(ii) Indirect Quotationとばかりに
そうはさせないとばかりにAs if so to say that someone wouldn’t let someone do that
(iii) Nounとばかりに
チャンスとばかりにAs if someone had decided that this were someone’s great opportunity
column45: Phrase (usually used in formal writing and formal speech)
column46: 【Related Expression: といわんばかりに; と言うよう/風に; と】

column2: A phrase that introduces a noun (or noun phrase) to describe the nature of someone or something.
column3: Which could/may be called; which can/could be described as
column9: (ksa).　あれは運命○○出来事だった。
column10: (ksa).　あれは運命とでも言うべき出来事だった。
column11: That was an incident that could be called fate.
column12: (ksb).　これはエッセイ的なサイトとでも言うべきでしょう。
column13: This should probably be described as an essay-like website.
column14: (a).　近いうちに試用版とでも言うべきものをお送りします。
column15: I'll send you something before long that could be called a trial version.
column16: (b).　ミュンヘンのシンボルとでも言うべきこの市役所は１８６７年から１９０８年にかけて建てられたものです。
column17: This city hall, which could be called Munich's symbol, was built between 1867 and 1908.
column18: (c).　我々は20世紀の技術の賜物とでも言うべき明石海峡大橋を渡った。
column19: We crossed the Akashi Strait Bridge, which could be described as a gift of 20th century technology.
column20: (d).　マイホーム計画最大のポイントとでも言うべきローンの組み方には、大きく分けると公的融資と民間融資の2種類があります。
column21: The ways of arranging a mortgage, which could be described as  the most important consideration when planning to buy a home, can be classiﬁed  into two types; government mortgages and private mortgages.
column22: (e).　彼を一言で表現するとしたら「ネットワークの旅人」とでも言うべきだろうか。
column23: If I had to describe him in a word, I would call him a "network  traveller."
column44:
(i) Noun1とでも言うべきNoun2
革命とでも言うべき出来事An event that could be called a revolution
(ii) Nounとでも言うべき
「現代版シンデレラ」とでも言うべきWe could call (her) a modern version of Cinderalla
column45: Phrase (usually used in formal writing and formal speech)
column46: 【Related Expression: と言う; である; のような】

column2: A conjunction that expresses the idea of “even (though)”.
column3: Even; any; although; though; even though
column9: (ksa).　医者○○時に病気になることもある。
column10: (ksa).　医者といえども時に病気になることもある。
column11: Even doctors sometimes become ill. (literally: Even though we call them doctors, there are times when they become ill.)
column12: (ksb).　いかなる名人といえども時には失敗することもある。
column13: Any master sometimes makes a mistake. (literally: No matter what kind of master he/she may be called, he/she sometimes makes a mistake.)
column14: (ksc).　東京に住んでいるといえども知らない都内の名所は沢山ある。
column15: Even though I live in Tokyo (literally: Even though I say I live in Tokyo), there are many sightseeing spots in Tokyo that I don't know.
column16: (a).　同時通訳は一瞬といえども気が抜けない。
column17: In simultaneous translation, you cannot lose your concentration even for a moment.
column18: (b).　科学技術の分野では、たとえグループ研究といえども個人の新しい発想によるところが非常に大きい。
column19: In the ﬁeld of science and technology, even group research is greatly dependent on individuals (coming up with) new ways of thinking.
column20: (c).　いかなる自動翻訳機といえども、完全に機械だけで自然言語を翻訳するのは難しい。
column21: No matter what kind of automatic translation machine (you use),  getting a natural-sounding translation solely from a machine is difﬁcult.
column22: (d).　当たらずといえども遠からず。
column23: Close, but not quite. (literally: Although  it is not exactly right, it is not far off.)
column24: (e).　世界広しといえども、東京の神田ほど多くの古本屋が一か所に集中しているところはほかにないだろう。
column25: Even though the world is a big place, nowhere else are there as  many used book stores concentrated in one place as there are in Kanda, Tokyo.
column26: (f).　筋力は少し衰えたといえども、彼はまだまだ若い選手に負けない集中力とスタミナを保っている。
column27: Although his strength has faded, he still maintains (levels of)  concentration and stamina comparable to younger players.
column28: (g).　いかに日本での生活が長いといえども、言葉の問題には常には遭遇する。
column29: Although I've lived in Japan for a long time, I constantly  encounter language problems.
column30: (h).　天性の才能を持ち合わせているといえども、絶え間ない努力と訓練なくして今日の彼女はなかった。
column31: Although she has God-given talents, she couldn't be what she is  now without her unceasing effort and training.
column44:
(i) Nounといえども
先生といえどもEven teachers
(ii) {いかなる/どんな}Nounといえども
{いかなる/どんな}技術といえどもAny technology; no matter what kind of technology it may be
(iii) Sinformalといえどもだ after Adjectiveなstem and Noun is often omitted
しっかり準備はしているといえどもEven though I’m well prepared
備えは万全(だ) といえどもAlthough the preparation is perfect
column45: Conjunction (usually used in formal writing and formal speech)

column2: A structure that introduces multiple perspectives when describing a person or a thing.
column3: In terms of both ~ and ~; in terms of ~ as well as ~; from the perspective of both ~ and ~
column9: (ks).　このコーヒーは味○○香り○○、申し分ありません。
column10: (ks).　このコーヒーは味といい香りといい、申し分ありません。
column11: This coffee is perfect in terms of both ﬂavour and aroma.
column12: (a).　内容といい話し方といい、見事なスピーチでした。
column13: It was a splendid speech in terms of content as well as delivery.
column14: (b).　声といい演技力といい、彼女は最高だ。
column15: She is the best from the perspective of both voice and acting ability.
column16: (c).　人柄といい才能といい、米倉さんに勝る人はいない。
column17: No one surpasses Ms. Yonekura in terms of both personality and ability.
column18: (d).　音楽の情感といい音の豊かさといい、こんな感動的な演奏を聴いたことがない。
column19: I've never heard such a moving performance, both in terms of the artist's emotion and the richness of the sound.
column20: (e).　家柄といい学歴といい、彼は非の打ちどころがない。
column21: He is just perfect, both in terms of his family and educational  backgrounds.
column22: (f).　スピードといいパワーといい、今の彼に勝てる選手はいない。
column23: No player can beat him now in terms of either speed or power.
column44:
Noun1といいNoun2といい
色といい形といいIn terms of both colour and shape

column2: A compound particle that introduces examples.
column3: Like; such as; among others
column9: (ksa).　ドイツ、フランス、ロシア○○国々が戦争に反対した。
column10: (ksa).　ドイツ、フランス、ロシアといった国々が戦争に反対した。
column11: Countries such as Germany, France and Russia opposed the war.
column12: (ksb).　このエンジンで一番困るのはパワーが弱い、製造コストが高いといった問題だ。
column13: The problems that are giving me the most trouble with this engine are things like weak power and high production costs.
column14: (a).　終身雇用、年功序列といった日本の伝統的雇用形態が崩れつつある。
column15: Japan's traditional employment practices, such as permanent employment and seniority systems, are (in the process of) falling apart.
column16: (b).　ここではBMWやベンツといったドイツの高級車が人気があるようだ。
column17: It looks like expensive German cars such as BMWs and Mercedes Benzes are popular here.
column18: (c).　学校選択制、そして基礎学力の向上といったテーマが今、全国で議論されている。
column19: Themes like school-choice systems and the improvement of basic academic skills are being discussed all over the country now.
column20: (d).　こんな機能があるといい、こんな情報が欲しいといったご意見・ご要望がありましたら、下記のアドレスに電子メールでお知らせ下さい。
column21: If you have opinions/requests such as "This kind of function  would be helpful" or "I want this kind of information," please let us know via  e-mail at the address below.
column22: (e).　一流大学から一流企業に就職すれば一生安泰の人生が送れるといった考え方はもう通用しない。
column23: It's no longer realistic to think that if you graduate from a  ﬁrst-class university and get a job at a ﬁrst-class company you are set for  life.
column24: (f).　ゴミを燃やせばダイオキシン二酸化炭素といった有害物質が排出される。またゴミの埋立地もあとわずかで満杯になる、しかも新たな埋立地がない、といった問題がある。
column25: If you burn trash, toxic materials such as dioxin and carbon  dioxide are emitted. There is also the problem that landﬁlls will soon be full  and, to make the matter worse, no new land for landﬁlls is available.
column44:
(i) Noun1、Noun2(、…) といったNoun
犬、猫といったペットPets like dogs and cats
(ii) Sentence1 (、Sentence2、Sentence3、…) といったNoun
持ち運びしやすい、容量が大きいといった特徴Such characteristics as portability and large capacity
column46: 【Related Expression: と言う; と言うような; などの】

column2: A phrase the speaker/writer uses to explain something in a brief/rough manner.
column3: I would say ~; ~ is how I’d put it
column9: (ks).　9月になって猛暑も一段落○○。
column10: (ks).　9月になって猛暑も一段落といったところです。
column11: I'd say the searing heat levelled off in September.
column12: (a).　ここは山というよりは、小高い丘といったところだ。
column13: I'd say that this is more of a (small) hill than a mountain.
column14: (b).　ホテルの部屋の広さはまあまあといったところでした。
column15: I'd say that the space in the hotel room was so-so.
column16: (c).　この大学の学部生と院生は合わせて6、000人といったところだ。
column17: Together, the number of undergraduates and graduates at this college is about 6,000.

column44:
(i) NPは別として
経験者は別としてExcept for those with some experience
決断の是非は別としてPutting aside the question of whether the decision was right or wrong
(ii) Sinformal か(どうか) は別としてだ after Adjectiveな stem and Noun is omitted
うまくいくか(どうか) は別としてPutting aside the question of whether or not something will go well
便利か(どうか) は別としてPutting aside the question of whether something is convenient (or not)
(iii) XかYかは別としてWhere X,Y=contrastive words
Noun1かNoun2かは別として英語か日本語かは別としてPutting aside the question of whether something is in English or Japanese
Adjectiveな1stemか Adjectiveな2stemかは別として便利か不便かは別としてPutting aside the question of whether something is convenient or inconvenient
Adjectiveい1informal nonpast(か)　Adjectiveい2informal nonpast(か) は別としていい(か)悪い(か) は別としてPutting aside the question of whether something is good or bad
V1informal nonpastか V2informal nonpastかは別として行くか留まるかは別としてPutting aside the question of whether someone will go or stay
(iv) X(affirmative)(か) X(Negative)(か) は別としてX is usually nonpast
行く(か)行かない(か) は別としてPutting aside the question of whether someone will go or not
高い(か)高くない(か) は別としてPutting aside the question of whether something is expensive or not
上手(か)上手じゃない(か) は別としてPutting aside the question of whether someone is good at something or not
日本人(か)日本人じゃない(か) は別としてPutting aside the question of whether someone is Japanese or not
(v) Sinformal場合は別として
Vinformal場合は別として一人で{行く/行った}場合は別としてExpect for the case in which someone will go/went alone
Adjectiveいinformal場合は別として授業が{高い/高かった}場合は別としてExcept for the case in which the tuition is/was expensive
Adjectiveなstem {な/だった}場合は別として場所が不便{な/だった}場合は別としてExcept for the case in which the location is/was inconvenient
Noun {の/だった}場合は別として原稿が英語{の/だった}場合は別としてExcept for the case in which the manuscript is/was in English

column27: No one is wearing a name tag, so I simply cannot figure out  who's who.

column29: I wonder what kind of feast they'll have for me to eat today. I  can't wait!
column30: (g).　いつのまにやら外は暗くなっていた。
column31: It got dark outside before I realised it.
column44:
(i) Sinformalのやらだ after Adjectiveなstem and Noun changes to な
{行く/行った}のやらI wonder if someone will go/went
{高い/高かった}のやらI wonder if something is/was expensive
不便{な/である/だった/であった}のやらI wonder if something is/was inconvenient
学生{な/である/だった/であった}のやらI wonder if someone is/was a student
(ii) Sinformalことやらだ cannot be used beforeこと Adjectiveな stem{な/である}こと;Nounであること
{行く/行った}ことやらI wonder if someone will go/went
{高い/高かった}ことやらI wonder if something is/was expensive
不便{である/だった/であった}ことやらI wonder if something is/was inconvenient
学生{である/だった/であった}ことやらI wonder if someone is/was a student
(ii) Sinformalやらだ after Adjectiveな stem and Noun is omitted
{行く/行った}やらI wonder if someone will go/went; whether someone will go/went
{大きい/大きかった}やらI wonder if something is/was large; whether something is/was large
上手{∅/だった}やらI wonder if someone is/was good at something; whether someone is/was skillful
学生{∅/だった}やらI wonder if someone is/was a student; whether someone is/was a student

column2: A structure to present things, events, actions, etc., as examples, reasons or possibilities.

column9: (ksa).　私は会議○○講習会○○でこのところ出張が続いている。

column17: We can't tell whether Hisako will come or not, so let's just go.

column19: Because I know nothing about art objects, I have no idea whether this pot is cheap or expensive.

column21: My suitcase is full now with a change of clothes and souvenirs  and other things.

column23: I write about my hobbies and my family in my blog from time to  time.

column25: Naoki did things like slurping his soup and talking with food  in his mouth—his table manners were horrible.

column27: My mind was somewhere else when I was talking with people  because I was mad at and jealous of Yoko, whom I saw talking happily with Andy.

column29: I heard that she speaks Japanese, but because I haven't heard  her speak yet, I have no idea whether she's good or bad at it.
column30: (f).　この仕事は自分にできるやらできないやら、やってみなければ分からない。
column31: I can't tell if l can do this job unless I try.

(literally: his ways of thinking are like those of  Japanese people to the extent that we cannot tell whether he is a Japanese or an  American.)
column34: (h).　貸してもらえるのやらもらえないのやら分からないお金を当てにしているのはよくない。
column35: It's not good to count on the money before you know if they  will lend it to you or not.
column44:
(i) XやらYやら
V1informal nonpastやらV2informal nonpastやら笑われるやら馬鹿にされるやらSomeone was laughed at and insulted, among other things
今日帰るやら明日帰るやらWhether someone will come home today or tomorrow
Adjectiveい1informal nonpastやらAdjectiveい2informal nonpastやら悲しいやら悔しいやら(I felt) sad and frustrated
いいやら悪いやらWhether something is good or bad
Adjectiveな1stemやらAdjectiveな2stemやら上手やら下手やらWhether someone is good or poor at something
Noun1やらNoun2やらクッキーやらチョコレートやらCookies, chocolates, and so on
本物やら偽物やらReal things and imitations; whether something is real or an imitation
(ii) V1informal(affirmative) やらV2informal (negative) やらWhere V1=V2
行くやら行かないやらWhether someone will go or not
行ったやら行かなかったやらWhether someone went or not
(iii) XのやらYのやら
V1informalのやらV2informalのやら行くのやら留まるのやらWhether someone will go or stay
Adjectiveい1 informalのやらAdjectiveい2 informalのやら新しいのやら古いのやらWhether something is new or old
Adjectiveな1stem{な/だった}のやらAdjectiveな2stem{な/だった}のやら上手なのやら下手なのやらWhere someone is good or poor at something

column2: A conjunction that presents an undesirable situation, which is assumed to be factual.
column3: If; if it is true that; if it is the case that
column9: (ksa).　知らない単語が出てくるたびに辞書を引いている○○いつまでたっても速く読めない。
column10: (ksa).　知らない単語が出てくるたびに辞書を引いているようではいつまでたっても速く読めない。
column11: If (it is true that) you look up unfamiliar words in the dictionary every time you encounter a new one, you will never learn to read fast.
column12: (ksb).　アパートがそんなに高いようでは私たちは東京には住めない。
column13: If (it is true that) apartments in Tokyo are that expensive, we cannot live there.
column14: (ksc).　成績が今までのようでは困ります。
column15: If you continue to show the level of performance you have to date, we will have a problem. (literally: If your performance is like what you have exhibited up to now, it's a problem.)
column16: (a).　今からそんなに文句を言っているようでは、この仕事をやり遂げるのは難しいだろう。
column17: If you complain like that now, it will be difﬁcult to complete this job.
column18: (b).　困った時に助けてくれないようでは友達とは言えない。
column19: If (it is true that) he doesn't help you when you are in trouble, you cannot call him a friend.
column20: (c).　朝が弱いようではこの仕事は無理でしょう。
column21: If it is true that) you have trouble getting up early in the  morning (literally: are weak in the morning), you probably won't be able to do  this job.
column22: (d).　千円程度の旅費払い戻しに4枚も5枚も書類が必要なようでは問題だ。

column25: If you're doing things like that now, there's no way you'll  meet the deadline.
column26: (f).　部下の面倒が見られないようでは上司失格だ。
column27: If (it is true that) you cannot take care of the people under  you, you are not qualiﬁed to be their boss.

column29: Even if we make an effort to increase research funding, with  the university facilities the way they are (literally: if the university  facilities are in their present condition), we won't be able to utilize the  funds effectively.
column30: (h).　次の試合も今日の試合のようでは、とても決勝には進めない。
column31: If we play the next game like (we did in) today's game, there's  no way we can advance to the ﬁnals.
column44:
(i) {V/Adjectiveい}informal nonpastようでは
行くようではIf it’s true/the case that someone goes/is going
弱いようではIf it’s true/the case that something/someone is weak
(ii) Adjectiveなstemなようでは
下手なようではIf it’s true/the case that someone is bad at something

二年のようではIf something is like two years ago

column2: A conjunctive phrase that presents　an undesirable hypothetical situation.
column3: If ~ happen to; if ~ at all; if ~ choose to
column9: (ks).　山野氏は非常に時間に厳しい人で、面会時間に5分も遅れ○○以後二度と会ってはもらえない。
column10: (ks).　山野氏は非常に時間に厳しい人で、面会時間に5分も遅れようものなら以後二度と会ってはもらえない。
column11: Mr. Yamano is very strict about time; if you happen to be even  five minutes late for an appointment with him, he won't meet with you again.
column12: (a).　私はタバコの煙に特に敏感で、近くで吸われようものならもう何事にも集中できなくなってしまう。
column13: I'm particularly sensitive to cigarette smoke, so when someone  is smoking nearby, I cannot concentrate on anything.
column14: (b).　ニューヨークでは信号が青に変わって一秒でも発進が遅れようものなら、すかさず後ろからクラクションを鳴らされる。
column15: In New York, if you happen to take even a second to move (your  car) forward after the trafﬁc light turns green, the driver behind you honks at  you immediately.

column17: On this island, you can have fun walking and swimming in the  ocean on sunny days, but if it happens to rain, there's nothing to do.
column18: (d).　この飛行機は前の座席との間隔が極端に狭いので、私のように大きい人間は、前の人に椅子を倒されようものなら、文字通り身動きできなくなってしまう。
column19: The seats in this airplane have an extremely small amount of  space between them, so if someone in the seat ahead chooses to lean back, large  people like me are stuck (literally: are in a situation in which they literally  cannot move).

column21: The frequent visits of door-to-door salesmen these days are a  real headache. The salesmen won't leave even if you say "no thanks," and if you  happen to let them in the house by mistake, they won't leave until you buy (their  products).

column24: (g).　この魚は猛毒を持っていて、間違ってそのトゲに刺されようものなら、患部が大きく腫れ上がってしまう。

column26: (g).　カウンセリングに行こうにも、その質や学派も様々でついつい懐疑的になってしまいます。

column28: (h).　その本は買おうにも絶版だった。
column29: Although I wanted to buy the book, it was out of print.
column30: (i).　携帯電話の電池が切れたので、電話をかけようにもかけられない。
column31: Because my cell phone battery is dead, I cannot make a call  even though I want to.

Vvolitionalにも(～ない)

column1: より・のほか（に）（は）～ない
column2: A phrase that conveys the idea that there is no other choice than to do something, or that something is true of only one of a select few things.
column3: There is no (other) choice but to; there is no other way than to; have to; nothing but; but; not ~ other than
column4: online reference
column9: (ksa).　公共の交通機関がないので、自分の車で行く○○。
column10: (ksa).　公共の交通機関がないので、自分の車で行く(より)ほか(に)(は)ない。
column11: Since there is no public transportation, we have no other  choice but to go there in your/my car.
column12: (ksb).　新聞はニューヨークタイムズのほか(に)は読まない。
column13: I read nothing but the New York Times. (literally: I don't read  any newspaper other than the New York Times.)
column14: (a).　アルバイトの仕事が駄目になったので、両親にお金を借りるよりほかになかった。
column15: Because I lost my part-time job, I had no choice but to borrow  money from my parents.
column16: (b).　友人がどうして気が狂ってしまったのかは推測するよりほかにはない。
column17: I can only speculate as to why my friend was acting crazy.
column18: (c).　信号機の故障で電車が止まってしまった以上、待っているよりほかない。
column19: Since the train is stopped due to a signal problem we have no  choice but to wait.
column20: (d).　国際的に活躍したければ英語を学ぶよりほかはないだろう。
column21: A person who wants to be internationally active will have no  choice but to learn English.
column22: (e).　秩序を回復するには権威の力を直接見せつけた容赦ない手段をとるよりほかはない。
column23: In order to restore order, there is no other choice than to  take ruthless means, directly demonstrating the power of our authority.
column24: (f).　モーツアルトが35年の生涯に６００曲以上の作品を書いたというのには、ただただ驚くよりほかはない。
column25: The fact that Mozart composed more than 600 pieces during his  life of thirty-ﬁve years is simply amazing (literally: leaves us no other  choice than to be surprised).
column26: (g).　典型的な科学者のイメージに合う人はアインシュタインのほかにはない。
column27: Nobody but Einstein ﬁts the stereotypical image of a scientist.
column28: (h).　学会に出席している学者は数人のほかは面識がなかった。
column29: All but a few of the attendees of the academic conference were  total strangers.
column44:
(i) Vinformal nonpast(より) はか(に)(は) ない
買う(より) はか(に)(は) ないThere is no other choice but to buy something
(ii) Noun{より/の}はか(に) はVnegativeない
アメリカ映画{より/の}はか(に) は見ないI see nothing but American movies
日本食は寿司{より/の}はか(に) は食べないI don’t eat any Japanese food other than sushi

column2: A dependent noun that marks the content of what the writer has learned.
column3: (I heard/It is said/etc.) that
column9: (ksa).　この度は本社営業部長にご栄転の○○、誠におめでとう存じます。
column10: (ksa).　この度は本社営業部長にご栄転の由、誠におめでとう存じます。
column11: I heard of your promotion this time to manager of the  headquarters' sales department. Please accept my sincere congratulations.
column12: (ksb).　地球環境保護の国際会議が来年当市で開催される由(である)。
column13: It is said that an international conference on global  environmental protection will be held in this city next year.
column14: (ksc).　野沢先生は来年一年ドイツにいらっしゃる由、伺っております。
column15: I've been informed that next year Professor Nozawa is going to  Germany for a year.
column16: (a).　第一子御出産の由、心からお祝い申し上げます。
column17: I heard that you gave birth to your ﬁrst child and I send my  heartfelt congratulations.
column18: (b).　当ホテルでのご滞在が快適でなかった由、誠に申し訳なく存じます。
column19: We learned that your stay at our hotel was not a pleasant one.  We are very sorry for that.
column20: (c).　交通事故のこと伺いました。お怪我などなかった由、ほっといたしております。
column21: I heard about the trafﬁc accident. I am relieved to hear that  you were not hurt.
column22: (d).　石垣島は運よく台風の通過コースからはずれたため被害が少なかった由。
column23: I was informed that there was not much damage on Ishigaki  Island because, luckily, the typhoon missed it (literally: swerved away from it).
column24: (e).　日本消費者連盟は、一部ウイスキーの不正表示に関して、公正取引委員会に申し入れる由である。
column25: It is said that the Japan Consumers Union is going to appeal to  the Fair Trade Commission regarding the dishonest labels on some whiskies.
column26: (f).　懇親会にご出席の由、吉本君から連絡を受けました。
column27: I heard from Mr. Yoshimoto that you will be attending the  reception.
column44:
(i) Nounの由
ご入院の由I heard of someone’s hospitalisation
(ii) {V/Adjectiveい}informal由

{高い/高かった}由I heard that something is/was expensive

column2: A conjunctive phrase that expresses the idea of concession.
column3: Even if; whatever/whoever/ etc.; no matter what/who/how/etc.; whether X or Y
column9: (ksa).　人が何と言○○、私は自分の子供を信じている。
column10: (ksa).　人が何と言おう{と/が}、私は自分の子供を信じている。
column11: Whatever (other) people say, I believe my child.
column12: (ksb).　頑固と言われよう{と/が}馬鹿と言われよう{と/が}、私は自分の信じることをやります。
column13: Even if people say I'm stubborn or stupid, I'll do what I  believe.
column14: (ksc).　あの教授は学生が分かろう{と/が}分かるまい{と/が}、かまわず授業を進めていく。
column15: That professor keeps lecturing (literally: advances his lecture)  regardless of whether his students understand it or not.
column16: (ksd).　報酬が多かろう{と/が}少ないかろう{と/が}、私はやるべきことをやるだけだ。
column17: Whether the compensation is high or low, l'll just do what I  have to do.
column18: (kse).　英語が上手だろう{と/が}下手だろう{と/が}そういうことは関係ない。
column19: It doesn't matter whether his English is good or bad.
column20: (ksf).　プロの作品だろう{と/が}素人の作品だろう{と/が}いいものは採用する。
column21: We'll adopt anything good, whether it's a work by a  professional or an amateur.
column22: (a).　人が何をしようと大きなお世話だ。
column23: Whatever I do, it's none of your business.
column24: (b).　費用がいくらかかろうとかまわない。何としてもこの訴訟勝たなければならない。
column25: We don't care how much it may cost. We have to win this lawsuit  by any means.
column26: (c).　彼はみんなが聞いていようがおかまいなしで、上司の悪口を言っている。
column27: He is saying bad things about his boss without regard to  whether or not others are listening.
column28: (d).　自分の子供たちが走り回ろうが飲み物をこぼそうが、親たちは叱りもしないで自分たちの話に夢中になっている。
column29: Even if their children are running around or  spilling drinks, the parents are too caught up in  their own conversation to scold them.
column30: (e).　彼女が結婚しようがするまいが、そんなことは私には関係ないことだ。
column31: Whether she's going to marry or not, it has nothing to do with  me.
column32: (f).　高かろうが安かろうが、必要なものなら買えばいい。
column33: Whether it's expensive or cheap, we should buy it if we need  it.
column34: (g).　参加者がたとえ一人であろうとツアーは予定通り行います。
column35: We're going ahead with the tour as scheduled even if we have  only one participant.
column36: (h).　日本人だろうがアメリカ人だろうが、そういうことは関係ない。好きになったら結婚する。
column37: It doesn't matter whether she is Japanese or American. If I  fall in love (with someone), I'll marry that person.
column44:

column45: Phrase (usually used in formal writing and formal speech)

column2: A conjunction that presents a reason or a cause.
column3: Because; because of; due to; therefore
column9: (ksa).　彼女はその美貌(の)○○、悩みも多い。
column10: (ksa).　彼女はその美貌(の)故(に)、悩みも多い。
column11: Because of her good looks, she also has many things to worry  about.
column12: (ksb).　結果にこだわりすぎる(が)故(に)、小さなことに心を奪われることになる。
column13: Because you want the end result to be perfect, you end up being  distracted by little things.
column14: (ksc).　これは極めてデリケートな問題だ。(それ(が)/その)故に、慎重に取り組む必要がある。
column15: This is an extremely delicate problem; therefore, we must  handle it very carefully.
column16: (a).　彼の精神は大病の故に強靭になった。
column17: His mind was strengthened because of his serious illness.
column18: (b).　電子テキストは改変と公開が容易であるが、この特徴故に公開されている電子テキストは元データを追跡することが難しい。
column19: Electronic texts are easy to revise and present to the public,  but because of these characteristics, it is difﬁcult to trace  publicly-displayed electronic texts back to their original data.
column20: (c).　携帯電話は便利故に、使い方を誤らないようにしなければならない。
column21: Because cell phones are convenient, we have to be careful not  to use them incorrectly.
column22: (d).　山は高いが故に尊からず。
column23: Mountains are not sacred just because they are tall.
column24: (e).　日本列島は南北に伸びているが故に、温度差が大きい。
column25: Because the Japanese archipelago extends north and south, the  temperature difference (within Japan) is great.
column26: (f).　アメリカでは今でも黒人であるが故に差別されるということがある。
column27: In the United States even now there are cases in which someone  is discriminated against because he or she is black.
column28: (g).　「我思う、故に我あり。」ーデカルト
column29: I think, therefore I am. -Descartes
column30: (h).　人はきっとミスをする。故に、それを前提とした対策を考える必要がある。
column31: People will certainly make mistakes; therefore, we need to  think of countermeasures based on that assumption.
column32: (i).　俳句は言葉が最小限に抑えられている。それ故に。表現されていないことを想像しなければならない。
column33: Haiku use a bare minimum of words. Therefore, one has to  imagine what is not expressed.
column44:
(i) {Noun(の)/Adjectiveなstem(な)}故(に)
天才(の)故(に) Become someone is a genius
便利(な) 故(に) Because something is convenient
(ii)Sinformal(が) 故(に) だ after Adjectiveなstem and Noun omitted
{間違いを/犯す/犯した}(が) 故(に) Because someone commits/commited an error
{美しい/美しかった}(が) 故(に) Because someone/something is/was beautiful
便利{である/だった/であった}(が) 故(に) Because something is/was convenient
天才{である/だった/であった}(が) 故(に) Because someone is/was a genius
(iii) Sentence1(それ(が)/その) 故に、Sentence2。
この議論は前提がおかしい。(それ(が)/その) 故に、結論も間違っているThis argument is based on a wrong premise. Therefore, the conclusion is also wrong

column2: A phrase that expresses the idea that someone/something necessarily or naturally causes something to happen.
column3: Be bound to; definitely; unmistakably; unquestionably; undoubtedly; without fail; without doubt
column9: (ks).　技術の発達は社会環境の変化をもたらさ○○。
column10: (ks).　技術の発達は社会環境の変化をもたらさずにはおかない。
column11: Technological advancements are bound to bring about changes to  social environments.
column12: (a).　コンピュータの普及とインターネット利用の拡大は大きな教育の変革を促さずにはおかない。
column13: The spread of computers and the expansion of Internet use are  bound to promote big changes in education.
column14: (b).　この映画は観る者に感動を与えずにはおかない。
column15: This movie is bound to move viewers. (literally: This movie  does not leave viewers without moving them.)
column16: (c).　この小説は我々に人間とは何かを考えさせずにはおかない。
column17: Without fail, this novel makes us think about what it is to be  human.
column18: (d).　この事故は日本とアメリカの関係に影響を及ぼさずにはおかないだろう。
column19: This accident will undoubtedly affect the relationship between  Japan and America.
column20: (e).　彼女は聴く者を魅了せずにはおかない音楽性とそれを表現する卓越した技術を持っている。
column21: She has a musicality that unfailingly captivates her audiences  and the superb technique to express it.
column22: (f).　環境や用途に合わせて動物たちがつくりあげる構造物は、彼らの知恵と工夫がいたるところに見られ、我々の好奇心を惹起せずにはおかない。
column23: Structures that animals construct according to their  environment and needs exhibit in every aspect their wisdom and ideas, and are  bound to arouse our curiosity.
column44:
VnegativeずにはおかないException: する→せずにはおかない
働かさずにはおかないSomeone definitely moves something

column46: 【Related Expression: 必ず; 間違いなく; 絶対に; ずにはおられない/おれない/いられない】

column2: A phrase meaning “without doing something”.
column3: Without ~ing; before (~ing); with no ~; if ~ do not; when ~ do not
column9: (ks).　インカ帝国を知ら○○南米大陸を語ることはできない。
column10: (ks).　インカ帝国を知らずして南米大陸を語ることはできない。
column11: You cannot talk about the South American continent without some  knowledge of the Inca Empire.
column12: (a).　我々のチームは最終日の最終戦を待たずして優勝が決定した。
column13: Our team won the championship before (literally: without  waiting for) the ﬁnal game on the ﬁnal day.
column14: (b).　自分の義務を果たさずして人の責任を問うべきではない。
column15: You should not call others to account when you have not  performed your own duties.
column16: (c).　文雄は宝くじが当たって労せずして大金を得た。
column17: Fumio won the lottery, receiving a large sum of money with no  effort.
column18: (d).　新しい議長の選出で期せずしてみんなの意見が一致した。
column19: In the election for a new chairman, unexpectedly (literally:  without expecting), everybody agreed (on who it should be).
column20: (e).　今勉強せずしていつするのか？
column21: If we/you don't study now, when will you study?
column22: (f).　荒木氏は自分の設計した建物の完成を見ずして亡くなってしまった。
column23: Mr. Araki died before (literally: without) seeing the  completion of the building he'd designed.
column24: (g).　ウイルスに感染した電子メールを社外の個人、団体に送信してしまい、意図せずして加害者になってしまった。
column25: I became an offender without meaning to after sending a  virus-infected e-mail to individuals and groups outside my company.
column26: (h).　敵を知らずしては戦えない。
column27: You cannot ﬁght without knowing your enemy.

待たずしてWithout waiting
練習せずしてWithout practicing

column2: A conjunctive phrase that indicates negative concession: “even if ~ not”.
column3: Without ~ing; even if ~ not; if ~ not
column9: (ksa).　今年の夏は涼しいので、エアコンを使わ○○過ごせそうだ。
column10: (ksa).　今年の夏は涼しいので、エアコンを使わずとも過ごせそうだ。
column11: It is cool this summer, so it looks like we can get by without  using the air-conditioner.
column12: (ksb).　シカゴには親しい友人が何人かいるので、ホテルに泊まらずともよい。
column13: Because I have several close friends in Chicago, I don't have  to stay at a hotel.
column14: (ksc).　こんなに安くヨーロッパへ行けるのなら、旅行好きならずとも行ってみたいと思うだろう。
column15: If you can go to Europe this cheaply, even if you don't  especially like to travel, you'll probably want to go.
column16: (a).　東京で会えずとも、大阪では必ず会える。
column17: (Even) if we cannot meet up in Tokyo, we will meet in Osaka for  sure.
column18: (b).　彼がどのくらいできるかはテストをせずとも見当がつく。
column19: I can guess how much he can do without even giving him a test.
column20: (c).　この程度の故障ならサービスセンター送らずともこの店で修理できます。
column21: We can repair this sort of trouble here at the store without  sending (the product) to the service centre.
column22: (d).　この携帯電話は音声による操作が可能で、数字キーを押さずとも声だけで電話をかけられる。
column23: This cell phone can be voice activated, so you can make a call  using just your voice, without having to punch any numbers.
column24: (e).　これからは特別な訓練を受けずとも使えるようなユーザーインターフェースが必要となるだろう。
column25: From now on it will be necessary to have a user interface that  doesn't require special training.
column26: (f).　この理論は難解なので、今すぐ分からずともよい。
column27: This theory is hard to understand, so it is all right if you  don't understand it right away.
column28: (g).　今回の野球ストは、これからのプロスポーツあり方を考えさせる出来事として、野球ファンならずとも注目する人が多かった。
column29: Many people, even if they were not baseball fans, paid  attention to the baseball strike this time because it (was an event that) made  them think about what professional sports should be like in the future (literally:  from now on).
